Entry.1:
November 1917

Had no sleep at night of course as everyone wished to express their opinion as to our going away. Marched onto Parade groundat 3.30am, then caught a special train to the City.

A great crowdwere at the station to welcome us, also to see the last possible glimpse of friends. I had several down and we formed a great party walking down in Column of "mob". Dad carried my Kit Bag; fortunately a motor car took them shortly after we started so it relieved us all of a job. As soon as we arrived at the wharf we said Goodbye to all our relatives and friends.

Embarkation rolls were called and every man had turned up. Going on the ship we were give our quarters in the aft part of the ship, which by the way is A.15 and "Port Sydney" by name. Leaving our kits down we went on deck to say a final goodbye to our people. I had a fine view of my friends till the ship pulled right out.She anchored off Rushcutters Bay till noon. Numerous launches crowded with people came around the ship. I again saw my people for a good while until the launch went back. An occasional ferry boat gave a a goodbye with the siren. The sea outside is calm. Had a good dinner and

several roll-calls etc, until 5pm when we had tea. Everyone went to bed early, and in hammocks. It was fun watching them trying to make themselves comfortable. None however succeeded, buthaving had no sleep the previous night, all very soon were quiet.
Entry.2:
Up at 5.30 AM although "Reveille" goes at 6AM and rolled our hammocks, putting them in the places set apart for that purpose. Had breakfast at 8AM but many vacant places could be seen. The meals so far are good, and our quarters spacious of course there are a number of men. The troop-deck extends the length of the ship having





Mess tables on either side, seating fourteen at each. Our equipment is put on the sides of the ship. The troops have the use of the Well-deck, the NCo's the Promenade and Boat deck for the Officers. She is doing about 11 knots an hour. A head sea is making her pitch,consequently many are sick. The wind is very cold. Have kept insight of land most of the time. Have been alllotted to different Boat Stations, I share a raft with nineteen others so everything is right for a bad day. Wrote letters home as we get to Melbourne tomorrow.
Entry.3:
Reveille at 5:30 AMwhen all had to turn out and then rolled hammocks. The

fresh water is turned on from5.30 to 6.30am, so there was arush for the basins. Shavingoperations could be seen inprogress in every availabledeck space. Had Physicalstunts on Promenade Deckfor half hour then camebreakfast. The rest of themorning was put in sittingon deck. In the afternoon theships Routine Orders wereread out, then a little lecturewas given. The heads cameinsight about 5 P.M. passingthe "Rif" at 6 P.M.. The seais very clam and most ofthe men are well again.A Sing-Song was held ondeck, when the O.C. of 31st Reinwas presented with the Flag of his

Reinforcements as we are not allowed to take it away to the front. Mr Middleton presented it on behalf of the Reinforcements. We are now making up to Port Melbourne.
Entry.4:
Arrived Port Melbourne early in the morning when we went up to the Admiralty Wharf. The Kit Bags of the men came down early and were put on board. Leave was given to all from 10am till 11pm much to our surprise. I acted guide to five men who have not been to Melbourne before, and showed them around the city. we went down by train making for the G.P.O when all sent letter etc. Had a great lunch

then had a walk around the town. finally going to the Church of England writing tent for a rest. From here we went through Coles Book Arcade and up to the Post Office.

Had Dinner in style, finishing up a good day by going to the theatre. Arrived home in good time very tired. Melbourne is the same as a year ago. Still have the old cable trams.
Entry.5:
Up as usual 5:30 AM and had the usual wash; these are habits which only occur twice a day. The troop train came down about 8am, troops numbering about eight hundred, composed of field artillery . A.M.C and flying corps, so the ship is

well packed.. People came down onto the wharf in thousands and made a very pretty scene with the many coloured dresses. The Victorians were given their quarters, then all went up on deck. Streamers kept those parted for a little while together until finally the vessel moved off amid the strain of Pack up your Troubles in you old Kit Bag. It was a pretty sight and very impressive, seeing those of our own nation, giving us, who are leaving for an unknown destination such a hearty farewell. It is a perfect day and lovely streaming along, the sea being very calm. Passed the heads at 4:30 PM. Sat on deck and had a read. The majority are

playing cards and other games of interest. It is calm outside at sea. Had issue of "Comfort Funds" at tea. These little gifts at eatables go well as a break from the other. Being tired from yesterday. I intended turning in early . The Hammocks are that close that it is impossible to fall out. This should be handy when the sea is unsettled.
Entry.6:
Still insight of land when Reveille went this morning, the sea is calm, but wind is coming up, which makes it very cold on deck. Had signalling all the morning, & a little boat drill, when the Victorians were allotted to their

stations. The decks are crowded when the men are dismissed & one finds it difficult to a get a good spot of rest. After dinner we had Boat Drill, I guess if the boat did sink, many would perish. Twenty men to one raft is the number, but many more are attached to some. We are now out of sight of land. it is cold on deck. Had a game of draughts then turned in. The majority of men are playing cards or reading
Entry.7:
Clock went back twenty minutes so had extra sleep. Had usual parade in morning. Passed two large ships about 8AM. Full serivce uniform for church parade, held on the Boat Deck at 10:15AM.

The service was brief but good, we stood up throught the service. Had Boat Drill in the afternoon again when those unallotted were given their raft number.

It is very cold on deck, having a head wind. The sea is calm.

Put in Spare time reading and writing. The band rendered some good music in the afternoo. Had a sing song at night, when popular hymns were sung. The sea appears to be coming up; had a little rain.
Entry.8:
Sea is very rough and the ship is tossing about. Clock went back some twenty minutes again so, we are having plenty of sleep. Have grown used to the

hammock now, and slept well. Had Gun Drill Lecture and signalling in the morning. Had to put our service boots on for the afternoon, as our feet would get soft if we continued to wear our sand-shoes. Had marching on deck for an hour and it went well. The band played. Had Boat Drill again, when everyone obtained their life belt, and reported to their respective stations. It is extremely cold on deck. Wrote a few letters and had a read, then turned in.
Entry.9:
Sea much calmer today. Had Physical Stunts as usual. From 9:30AM till 11:30AM had lecture on Batteries and angles. Whale passed by close to the ship, we also

passed a dead whale of good size. The birds were there in large numbers having a Xmas feed. Had a good walk around the decks in afternoon with service boots on. The band played. Had Morse signalling till the end of the parade. Had a concert to night by the Victorians, they were very good.
Entry.10:
A fresh wind has come up making it very cold. Had Physical Drill as usual as a little shipping. Had lectures till 11:30 AM. Land sighted at 10AM believed to be King Georges Sound so should strike the Cape tonight and Fremantle in a day. Passed two ships. Very strong wind blow-ing making ship roll. A few

waves came in the Ports also on deck wetting a few of the chaps. Had route march as usual. Down below is favourite tonight, they are just issuing the hammocks for the night. Measles has broke out on board.

Thrusday
Entry.11:
Up as usual and did usual Physical Jerks. Am on water Picquet today, a very soft job. Have to guard the fresh water tap. There are three to each place so do one hour on and two off. Passed Cap Leeuwin about Midnight; the ship is now going in a Nor-West direction. Ship is rolling a good deal, there being a following sea. A party had rifle shooting at a target some few hundred yards off representing a submarine.

the firing was excellent for first time. Had Boat Drill soon after dinner when everyone rushed for belts and went to respective stations. No sooner had we our belts away than it went again. We are gradually getting perfect. The main fault is congestion at the stairways.Had a good read all day, then played drafts at night. An Impromptu Concert was held. Have left Australia making for Colombo. Since leaving Melbourne the only land sighted was King Georges Sound, and that we lost in a couple of hours.
Entry.12:
On water guard early this morning. Have inspection by a Medical Officer every morning owing to Measles breaking out.

Had usual lectures morning and afternoon. Have changed our parade ground to other side of deck. We are to change each week. Had shooting at target in water again. It is much warmer today as we are going Nor Nor West. Sea and wind is still following. Had route march around deck, rather warmer than usual. Our meals are still good. Most men are up on deck tonight as it is much cooler than down between decks.
Entry.13:
Had no Physical Stunts today, as we had to get dressed for a full Kit Inspection. This meant a lot of trouble having to take up our Kit Bags, hammocks and Life Belts, besides getting into a full marching order dress.

Fell in at 9am and stayed till noon without any signs of an Inspection. After dinner we bought our gear down and packed it away. The temper of all on the Mess Deck is now rather of a higher pitch than usual. Had a Boxing Tournament on Promende Deck. Many good bouts were witnessed by a large number of officers and men. Good positions went very early, late arrivals found seats near the funnel of the ship or on the Bridge. Any place out of bounds is always recognised as the best place. After tea a very good concert was held. It is getting very hot on deck and below. The awnings were put up today . The sea is calm, ship is making good way.
Entry.14: Lovely morning sea is calm, sat in the cool till breakfast. Had Egg and Bacon for Breakfast. Egg was not much good. Had a good Divine Service at 10:15AM on the Well Deck for'ard. It is now very hot especially between decks. Wrote letters all the afternoon. also read a little. At night developed a film then sat on deck in the cool. Most of us sit and sleep on deck. A Sing Song was also held tonight.
Entry.15:
Very hot in sun. The 31stReinftshad their first washing day Parties of twenty eight men took their turn at doing their washing. Two basins of water was each man's allowance, one to wash in,

the other to rinse them. Having only twenty minutes, the various articles received little attention, consequently, they didnot appear to have gained much through the process. Our drying took place on the lower portions of the rigging, fastening them by tying the sleeves together. Had usual route march, until the "Alarm" went; then the hustle and rush took place, especially getting down the companion way. Have at last donned the Tropical Dress, and allowed to sleep on deck. Wrote letters at night then read a little. More submarine practice took place. We are near Cocos Island, made historical since the war.
Entry.16: Slept on Promenade Deck. Found it rather hard, yet it was lovely and cool. Did Physical Stunts as usual Pay Day; received a small amount. Had letter and route march. A concert was held at night. Wrote letters most of spare time. Rifle practice continued today at Submarine target. Good shots were recorded. Much hotter than yesterday, especially down between deck. Sea calm.
Entry.17:
Very cloudy and humid. Rained during the night, causing sleepers on deck to scramble under shelter. Had Physical Stunts, lectures. Heavy rainfall at 11AM when you could not see a hundred yards ahead. Flying fish are numerous in these waters. Had Boat Drill today.

Was half through a shave when the alarm went so had to go up as I was. The interstate "Tug-o-War took place when Victoria defeated the New South Wales team. Wrote letters, being the last opportunity we have before the closing of the mail for Colombo. Very hot down, below.
Entry.18:
Deck sleepers were again awakened in the early hours of the morning by the rain. Had the usual "Stunts" After breakfast we did Knotting and Lashing till Dinner. Had afternoon off as the Sports were held. Many different events took place. Sparfighting proved the most interesting, many contests being very funny. The sack race,

Potato Race, and Cock fighting entertained a good crowd; on the whole everyone enjoyed the Sports all events being carried through satisfactorily. It is very hot still. The wind is now head on, so there is a good breeze blowing. The mail closed for Colombo today, so letter writing is over for a few days. I am not sorry.
Entry.19:
Had usual Physical Stunts before breakfast. Have changed our parade ground again, we are now on the Starboard Side of the Boat Deck. It is very hot up there as compared to the other deck. Had Signalling and Gun Drill lectures. A cool wind is blowing. The rain still pours down at night, Crossed the line in the afternoon.

The announcements of tomorrow's ceremony was given from the Bridge.
Entry.20:
All Officers are now engaged in censoring letters, there being over fifteen thousand letters sent in. The Colonel has fixed the next mail at three letters per head. He said the Officers were overworked ? Yetthe Colonel is trying hard to get us leave at Colombo. Had usual lecture this morning. At 11AM we started our " Route March" doing several times around the deck. After dinner I wandered up onto the Boat Deck as I thoughtto secure a good position for the "Neptune Carnival", but all positions of note were taken. However I worked my way in to

the front and so had a rather crushed view. Long before "Father Neptune" appeared all the deck was crowded, even on the Engine Room places were secured. "What was that?" A noise certainly, for the procession headed by a band whose instruments were not in harmony, made its way along the Well Deck to the Promenade Deck. With "Father Neptune" walked his Doctor and attendants.

Owing to the large number of men on board who have not been across the line, two "Sports" from each Reinforcement represented the unit. One at a time they came onto the platform, where the "Doctor" sounded their chest and heart, giving them a pill of soap. Sitting on a chair, back to the bath the Barber's assistant lathered their

face, mouth and eyes particularly. The Barber with a razor more like a scythe shaved their face. They were then rudely pushed into the water and "Ducked" by two "heavy weights". Several Officers went through the procedure, receiving extra lather and ducking. Everyone thoroughly enjoyed the afternoon. At the finish the hose was let loose with the result the Colonel orderd the "Alarm", thus ended the afternoon Sport.

At night a very good concert was held on the Promenade Deck. The night was perfect.
Entry.21:
Had Divine Service at 10 AM but could not hear the service being too far back. Enjoyed the hymns. It is very hot still.

wrote a few letters in the afternoon. Had Sing Song at night. Expect to get into Port tomorrow. They are drawing to see who is doing duty whilst at port.
Entry.22:
Arrived in sight of land early in the morning, when we made for the breakwater passing into the harbour about 9:30 AM, and anchored just inside. The Colonel went ashore to try and get us leave as the "Wireless" sent asking for same was refused, owing to another lot rioting there on Saturday before. He arranged that five hundred to go ashore at a time, for three hours each. Sixty out of each unit went at 2 PM, four barges taking us to the Town Pier. Forming up we marched through the town.

to the Barracks, where, after a lecture we were dismissed till 5.30 PM only having two hours leave. With a mate we went to the G.P.O. then took a Rickshaw to a firm we knew and did a hurried shopping hour. Bought several souvenirs of Colombo. Taking a Ricksha we went to the YMCA leaving the Parcels to be sent on home. Had a look round the town then made back to the Barracks. The town is the same as I have already described in the other diary. A few fine buildings have been recently built. Electric Trams also run to the Railway Station from the Pier. It is very hot and humid ashore. This is the Monsoonal Period. Took several snaps but the light was bad.

Every man played the game, all turning up to time Marched down to the Pier. Every man had his hands full, either bananas, Cocoanuts, brass work or numerous oriental curios. The Natives poured out of the shops to see the procession. Came back in four barges taking us about half hour to get back.
Entry.23:
Very Hot still. Am on Guard today. Mounted at 7.30 AM, I am on first relief doing from 8AM till noon. Another batch of five hundred went ashore this morning. Had till 1 PM. They returned back at 2 PM. Eighteen men have failed to report. The last batch have just gone. Took several photos from the ship. The tables are laden with Bananas etc. Have finished coaling and watering. They are still taking

off frozen meats, several barges have already gone. The natives' gabble is getting monotonous, they are just in the hold alongside. The third batch have returned. Am on Guard from 8PM till midnight. A terrific Monsoonal storm came up about 5PM, when it poured for two hours, land in close vicinity was obscured. Lightning was vivid while it lasted. The party ashore arrived back at 9 PM very wet and down hearted, with a bad impression of Colombo also. The Singalese continued working all night, making a terrific noise, especially with their gabble, with the result none of the Mess Deck went to sleep. till the late hours of the morning. Finished taking on the tea about 8 AM.
Entry.24: Up early as Icould not sleep. Very humid, the heat is almost a killer. Numerous divers around the ship. calling out "me di(ve) di(ve)for threepence etc. "These men are common here. Some are good divers. Had an "alarm" at 11 AM and stood by for over an hour. The Boat pulled out at noon, we were not sorry, for it is much cooler at sea, than in port. Had lectures in the afternoon, but these did not go down too well, all being tired. It is calm at sea. Plenty of "cheap" cigars are running around the deck in the hands of Gunners. I have fifty so will "swank" too. Did a little reading. Sent a few cards off this morning with the Y.M.C.A official. They do great work amongst the troops.
Entry.25: Rained very hard all night, so now all have to sleep down on the Mess Deck, which is extremely hot and muggy. The atmosphere is still humid. Had no Physical Culture as it was too wet. After breakfast we had signalling and lectures. In the afternoon we had a few Military Orders read out to us, particularly matters dealing with dealing with A.I.F.in France during operations in the last offensive. It is still hot. The days are short, night falls quickly,the sea is calm. A concert was held on deck. Not bad.
Entry.26:
Sea very calm. There is no wind consequently the heat is terrific. Had usual lectures during the day. Have changed our parade ground again to the Promenade

Deck aft. It is much cooler down here. Developed several films at night, they all turned out very good, in fact, better than I thought they would. Had an "Alarm" soon after the "Lights Out" when we were just getting to sleep. it was a "Dinkum" pyjamas parade. Some cursed. _________X ?
Entry.27:
Had usual "Physical Stunts"; sea is calm, although it is raining heavily. We are getting use to the rain waking us up at night, for each night sees us disturbed at some unearthly hour. Had lectures till noon. A chap died of Measles about 9 AM and all on board had to attend the burial at 3 PM. After the service volley were fired and the corpse was put into the sea. " The Last Post" was sounded.

Did little reading, then after tea went to the concert which was held on the Promenade Deck. It was not bad.
Entry.28: Sea is still very calm. Had usual Divine Service at 10 AM. Could not hear sermon being too far away. Had a read before Dinner, then wrote letters, also entering Snaps up in my book.
Entry.29:
Started Mess Orderly this morning for a week. It is not a bad stunt as you have plenty of time off this means, time to write a few letters. The time goes slowly. Paid today, the huge sum of ten shillings. We brought our universal Kit Bags up today, so had an opportunity of repacking our bags

The sea is calm, heat is still over the mark. The usual rain storm came down last night.
Entry.30: A fresh breeze sprung up during the night, and it indeed proved a blessing. It is on our side of the ship too. Did Mess Orderly duties, also wrote a few letters. A little swell is on. We are now under strict regulations in respect to smoking on deck. Had a washing day.
Entry.31:
Issued with a Cap, Comforter, pair of socks, flannel shirt and handkerchief form the "War Chest" Sydney. They are very well made. Some had letters in them.

Wednesday 5th December 1917

Passed two Islands near Socotra Is about 8 AM, they sighted the main

land some little time after, keeping insight of it ever since.The coast is barron and precipitous, a few fishing boats are about & on the shore, with the aid of glasses you can see small villages. It is cool, sea calm. Did usual Mess Orderly's job.
Entry.32: Lost sight of land about noon. Usual routine of ship went through. There is no news. Expect to strike PerunIsland early in the morning. Our Attestation Papers checked today. Getting ready for disembarkation.
Entry.33:
Entered the Red Sea early this morning. British Cruiser stopped us then gave us the "Proceed-Goodluck" Kept insight of land for a few hours. The coast is very precipitous

and against the sky of pale Blue was very picturesque, despite the fact that it is barren. Passed many ships during the day, and have just passed a lighthouse on a huge rock. Mess Orderly's job today was a "stunner" having to scrub down the side of the ship nearMess tables. A fresh breeze is blowing. Several of us went on top of Hospital and had a "Bosker"sing song, raking up all the old songs, at the same time bringing back memories of Sydney and time gone, perhaps such that will never return.
Entry.34:
Finished Mess Orderly today. In afternoon went to see finals of Boxing Tournament. A huge crowd was there. Had concert at night better than usual. No land has been

seen today. The sunsets are not bad. Sea is calm. Weather hot in day cold at night.
Entry.35:
Usual church service. A good delivery by the chaplain entitled "Stand Fast" Had read in afternoon also fixing up my Camera. Passed a couple of vessels before noon. Had "Birthday Party" ?on account of Woods who is now twenty. Some spread of (the usual ) with Lemonade and tinned fruits. Three of the Mess have Birthdays this week. Pity we are not on ship longer than Wednesday next. It is cool on deck. There has been several raids on gambling parties on deck this afternoon. A practical joke just happened. Several of out chaps sleeping on

deck received a few buckets of water over them. they dont know who did it - They are now changing. A sing song was held on deck at night.
Entry.36: Passed a couple of Lighthouses during the day. It is very cold on deck. Had lectures in morning, and in afternoon we cleaned our equipment up, for going ashore. Most of us slept down below, it being too cold on deck. This is our last night in the hammocks.
Entry.37:
Stowed hammocks and blankets down the hold early this morning, so have to sleep in overcoats tonight. Land is on either side being close to African Coast. Extremely cold on deck.

Passed several vessels. One had

gone aground during the night and was being tugged off by another vessel. Had signalling all the morning , also in afternoon. Have to sleep on floors tonight. Expect to get in about 8 PM, when we disembark in the morning. It is very cold. Had no mess utensils for tea, so had to use our Mess Tins. The chaps are merry, evidently because trip is over, and fresh ports and places to see in near future.
Entry.38:
Came into Port Tewfik early in the morning, pulling alongside one of the wharves. The sick were taken off first then the "Advance Party went off. Went onto parade about 8AM staying there till 10.30 AM. Then formed up on the wharf, leaving our

Kit bags behind, a party being detailed to bring them on trucks. Several large vessels are in port. Had a good four miles walk to the camp. Went through Port Tewfik, this place is very dirty, has poor buildings, and streets are narrow. A train connects this place to Suez a distance of about one mile, mostly, a bridge of stone, with the sea on the other side and canal on the other. Had a rest for a few minutes. Took a snap of the chaps sitting down then one of self with four niggers. The chief vehicle of working class is a frail cart very small pulled by a donkey. This animal is used more so than the horse. The latter is used in the "Garry"the chief passenger conveyance.The town of Suez is filthy. Streets and buildings alike are dirty. The

houses are constructed of stone and plaster, half finished, with flat roofs made with rough spars with plaster thrown in between. Years 
ware
wear have made the houses, originally white, very dirty. The "Gippos"or perhaps the "Arabs" are equally dirty, having a habit of hanging out the windows, and doors. The Railway runs through the town, having a high iron railing, on each side of the lines for protection to public. The gauge is 4" - 81/2 ".There are three classes - natives of course travel third. The file of our Army also have that privilege (unfortunately) - the trains are slow. Passed though a couple of suburbs, mostly natives and the same kind of streets etc to the town there are very few buildings in

the true sense of the word. Little cultivation is to be seen; the soil is mostly sand and pebbles. A Date palm is to be seen now and then. Arrived at the camp about (13) thirteen o'clock. (The system of time keeping here, is different to that of English speaking nations). The time goes from 1 AM till 12 o'clock (noon) then goes up to twenty four oclock, which is midnight. Had our dinner of "Bully Beef & Biscuits", after which we were allotted to tents, eight men in each, so we have ample room to sleep. Nearby is an aerial school for advanced pupils; thus, above our heads several planes constantly are flying. None of us need that portion of "Physical Stunts" "Head Raise" for we walk looking to the sky. This however, will soon wear off, and in time we will not heed them. Had two blankets issued, they are

not bad. Had tea of bread & "Bully Beef"; washed down with China tea. We enjoy the tea, after such solid "tucker". This camp is known as "The Australian Rest Camp" formerly used by the French. It has some two hundred and fifty tents each capable of holding easily ten men. Has a canteen, but it is not much good. There are four taps to wash 
with
 at, equal to at present four hundred men one tap, equals a very large rush which equals a scramble, and finally that you do not get a wash at all. You are lucky to get your tooth brush wet. The showers however, have originated from the over strained working of some officer's brain, for we have two showers (each with a tin above holding a bucket of water. You carry the water to the place, climb up putting the water in. Now your

shower. You turn it on and alas six little streams of water trickle down. This is your shower. But cheers, we have a Y.M.C.A here, so we are lucky in that respect. Did a fatigue at night, getting stuff of the trucks. Went to bed tired. Rolled up in the two blankets with waterproof under, & over coat as pillow. Very Cold during the night, as this is winter. Will be prepared tonight. Joints are stiff through the hard ground.
Entry.39:
Woke up early then waited till the "Reveille" went at 6:30 AM. Folded our blankets up putting them outside the tent, also our Kit Bags, so as the ground could be well airedwhere we sleep. Had breakfast of "Bully Beef" and tea. Had a so called wash. Parade at 9:30AM. Just "fell in" and Camps standing

Orders were read out ot us. The rest of the day we watched the aeroplanes. Had Bacon (almost raw) Onions & Spuds for dinner. We were to go on leave this afternoon, but MIlitary like it was stopped at the last moment. Had to vote for the Conscription Question today. Most of the chaps voted "NO". Hope the remainder of Australian people do the same. The days are perfect; sun just warm with a lovely cool breeze blowing. The sky is a little paler that that of Australia, otherwise you would think the weatherAustralian. The Camp is on a level piece of land of hard sand which stretches to the sea on the West and to the Railway on the East. To the South lies Suez. The twilight is very short. It is getting very cold now although it is only sixteen o.clock (4PM). Had tea of Bread Jam and tea. Went

to YMCA tent and did a little writing. The place was crowded. It is very cold.
Entry.40:
Had a good sleep during the night, up at Reveille 6.30 and had a wash. The taps are a good way from our tents. Had very plain breakfast of Bully Beef & bread. On Fatigues today. One section of each Reinforcements do all fatigues while the others go on leave. We go on leave tomorrow afternoon. Pitched tents till dinner time. Had Bacon and turnips. Egypt is waiting on the food from Port Sydney and a couple of other ships of food. Dug two houses or rather the foundation so as to lift them up. Some work. We didn't overwork ourselves.Shifted our tents again, so as unit will be compact. Had a sing song

in YMCA the chaps who have just arrived back, do not think much of the town. It is cold as the sun goes down. One of the aeroplanes came down this morning, breaking propeller and machinery. These planes travel at 60 miles an hour having horse power of about 80. The wings are made of fabric or oiled silk. On each wing and at end are flaps which elevate or depress plane. These are worked by either pilot or observer.
Entry.41:
Did fatigues in the morning as usual. Had leave from 2PM till 9PM. Went in with two other tent mates. The town is about two miles from the camp. Some went in by Garries others on Donkeys while the remainder walked. Had a general walk around the various streets

in the market place. The streets are narrow and dirty, also the shops, which are very small, and in disorderly fashion. Silks are the chief articles of interest to the troops. Bought a few Post Cards of different Ports in Egypt. Had a sort of a tea at a hotel. The best in the place, (except for the officers'). Returned back to camp about 9PM.
Entry.42:
Digging trenches all day, so there is little to tell. The 31st Reinforcement got all fatigues as we have "rotten" Officers who think of themselves.Most of the chaps took "French Leave" at night. I stayed in , and repacked Kit Bag, so as to be ready for the morning when we leave again. The lads came home about 7'Oclock, and have a lot to talk about. A lecture on Egypt was given by some chap. Very

interesting indeed. About two thousand men arrived today per the "Nestor" mostly Infantry, so we have a big camp now. Very tired so will turn in as there will be little sleep in morning & night of tomorrow. Posteda letter home.
Entry.43:
Up as usual at 6AM. Cleaned the lines up, then printed a few snaps of photos taken on Port Sydney. Took our Kit Bags over to the train some fifty yards distance; Then had a look at a few planes. Had a tea of Bully Beef & Biscuits as usual. Fell in at 6PM entrainingat 7PM. The train left the siding at 8PM. Played cards for a while then settled down for a nights unrest. Some gave various songs and unearthly noises till about

midnight. Most of us were sorry to leave this camp so soon. Arrived at Alexandra 5:30AM, so we saw little of Egypt. One chap described it as "going to a concert and looking through the Key Hole. However we saw the Nile and a few other stations.
Entry.44:
A dull morning - formed up and set to work to get Kit Bags off trucks. This took about an hour. Got a little hot water from a and made a cup of soup, which went down well. Took our Kit Bags on board the SS"Karoa" 7000 tons speed 18 Knots a British India vessel. Our quarters are aft of starboard side of Troop Deck. It is pitch dark ( port holes closed ) with an electric light here and there. The deck is low and has a strange damp odour mixed with smell of paint, this makes

more trouble, to the weary overcrushed Gunners who have no tea in view & the floor as bed, together with the ever increasing vibrations of the ship, as she puts ever ounce of steam to send her flying a good eighteen knots through the danger zone of the Mediterranean Sea. There are about two thousand men on board, another cross channel vessel has a thousand Infantry on board. We are escorted by four destroyers the much advised "White Ensign"One is for'ard , other aft and on either side. The "Karva" has about twenty four life boats, and numerous up to date rafts, with hooks and oars on them. we have to sleep in uniform life Belt & Water bottle near at hand. The bad writing is caused through ship vibrating so much. Turned in early being very tired.
Entry.45:
Did not sleep much as night, the smell on deck being vile this was cleaned up by natives during the day it being dirty rotten water down the Hold close by. Picked a ticket for guard while on ship. The 31st again, get all the "good fatigues. There are sixty of us on, doing two hours on and four hours off. We are guarding insignificant positions, such as water tap with the water turned off. Had a little sea runningall day, making this tub roll. All on hand wish she would go right over. Have had no food excepting for Bully Beef & Biscuits for now over a week. The meat on board like the bread cannot be eaten. This is the first batch of white soldiers to travel on her having taken on previous trips Indians. Engines stopped for two hours about midnight owning to a breakdown. The escorts

which are constantly on either side, some mile away came over, to see what was doing. Have been going much slower since.
Entry.46: On guard from 6AM till 8AM. Sea very calm. Destroyers still in usual place. Men are sick of this vessel having nothing to eat excepting the Biscuits & Beef. Have to be ready to disembark tomorrow at 8AM, also not to see our Kit Bags till we get to England. The decks are crowded with men. Have not had our clothes off since leaving Suez. We feel anyhow. Rained heavily during the night. Chaps sleeping for'ard were "ducked" severely when she dipped her nose under the swell.
Entry.47:
Arrived in sight of land about 6AM, very low lying coast with range of hills in

background. We are in Gulf of Taranto. arrived in Bay of the same name, which is unprotected to seas, although to enemy craft, has strong submarine nets, and guns on fort at entrance. Anchored off the Old Town till 3PM as the entrance is only opened between 8AM - 9AM and 3 PM - 4PM. Numerous mine sweepers came out to do their most dangerous daily task at sea. The vessels work in pairs having nets between and steaming slowly ahead in danger zone. An Italian super-sub-marine circled continuously around the Bay afterwards proved to be its trial trip. By appearance it did about fourteen knots; had its conning Tower painted various colours, so as to be less discernible. At one time we had four branches of the Army very prominent. In the air, Aeroplanes and a Dirigible were flying; on the sea Destroyers and Battleships were slowly

steaming into the harbour; thirdly, we had the submarine close at hand. Then ourselves who represented the land portion.Steamed into the Harbour of Taranto slowly; here, perhaps, we witnessed one of the most impressive and enthrillingincidents of our lives. On one side of the entrance ( which is only wide enough to allow one ship to enter) which is a fort, hundreds of sailors and soldiers cheered and cheered; the other side grouped hundreds of soldiers and civilians, on the Promenade or rather street who also cheered and waved, this lasting till we rounded the corner. The city like Malta is built on the water's edge, some forty feet up, thus standing out conspicuously. The houses seem to be plainly built, while they are painted different colours. The new town is on the West of the entrance, the old on the East. Passed

many warships of the Italian Fleet, these in turns cheered us. There were three large Battleships. This is one of the four Italian Naval Bases. Above, the droning Buzz of the three Hydroplanes, drew our attention. They gave us a good exhibition in the air, also landing on the water, where they slide along for some distance. a close view showed that the engine is above the Heads of the Pilot and Observer, who sit together. They appear much safer than the land planes. As usual the troops were all over the ship looking at the very interesting sights. However one needed more than a pair of eyes for our attention was suddenly fixed on a trail of foam in the water caused by a torpedo, which cleared our bows by twenty yards. we did not see it till about one hundred yards off the ship. A submarine had fired a "dummy" at us

It stopped a few hundred yards off, where it sent out flashes intermittently. A launch took it back. Hunger was forgotten now by all, for events such as we had witnessed in the last hour, had been far too interesting to think of our Bully Beef etc. Hydroplanes came quiet close to the ship afterwards. On the shore is a camp which I believe tomorrow we will know more of than at present. Have to sleep on decks with nothing but uniform, as they took blankets and Beltsaway.
Entry.48:
Up at 5AM and had a wash. None of us slept well, being very cold at night. Had a little Bread & Margarine for breakfast. Cleaned up the ship alittle for all wished that the time would hurry and let us off. The first batch went off in two Barges ( these were used in Gallipoli ) under the command of a Naval officer. They counted the ship and officers out a few times.We left at

10AM. We heartily counted out the officers and ship as we left her side. Formed up on jetty, then went up a hill to our huts which are shaped like a semi-circle at either end; about twenty feet wide 45 feet long, capable of holding forty men comfortably. Between each two men a mosquito net is placed, owing to the pests in summer. Had breakfast at 11AM of good stew and bacon & fresh bread. How we all smiled when eating it. Like children sitting at a Birthday party. Had orders read out to us, and all the lads burst out laughing when this was read out :- "Camp Standing Orders by Sir 
Percy
 Cunningham". Near by, just a few hundred yards away is the original Marconi Station. It is of course on a large scale. Had a game of soccer, on a muddy field with about six inches of mud on our boots. Some went over in the mud. Much to the fun of

many spectators. A train load of soldiers of Jamaica had just arrived from France, the weather being too cold for them. They talk excellent english. The camp covers a large area, but we are at present confinedto our own area, as measles have again broken out. Issued with three blankets as it is very cold here at night. Had hot dinner at 7PM of good hot stew and tea, which went down far too quick. Wrote alittle then turned in and had a good sleep.

December
Entry.49:
Had a little rough play before we dressed at 7.30 AM. Had breakfast then formed up for church parade which was held in the open in front of the huts. The sermon was one of thanksgiving, havingarrived over the dangerous waters of Mediterranean Sea safely. Did alittle printing in afternoon, then

wrote a few letters. It is very cold. especially when the sun goes down. Sunset is 4PM, darkness sets in very early. We are to be here sometime as measles have not yet been checked The chaps are playing soccer to get warm. Took a couple of photos of interiors of Hut and Marconi Wireless Station. Taking snaps is rather dangerous, as it is strictly forbidden. Had excellent lunch today of cheese, margarine, jam five ounces of Bread and paste, quite a feed for us. This is the first time we have ever felt right just below the belt since leaving the Port Sydney.
Entry.50:
On Hut picquet, so as to get films cut up and do a little printing .They turned out to be good. Had a route march into the country. The land is well cultivated, the growing of olives



seem to be the chief plant grown. The hedges are used as fences. The soil is very heavy and clayey, and at present nearly underwater. We went about three miles then turned back, having enjoyed a good march, also seeing a little of the country. Had the afternoon to ourselves, putting in time playing games not too tame. Settled down to write for the night but at 8.30 PM the officer came in detailing about forty of us for picquet as a couple of hundred chaps had gone to Taranto on French Leave. Marched to the lorries which whirled us into town a distance of three miles. Here we went in batches all over the town hunting up the sight seeing crowd. Being full moon, we looked at the town more than anything. There were more men let go than taken as this particular work is against the

grain of most of us. The town can be best explained by saying it is many York Streets of Sydney, with solid, four story houses having no windows but doors which open onto small verandahs. Most of the buildings are of white stone. In the wide streets are gardens, the streets are long and straight like in Melbourne. Had alittle excitement about 11 PM a wild Irishman refused to get into the lorry and threatened to stab the Colonel with a jack knife, two Tommiesgot him, then they heaved him in. Came back in lorries, being at least satisfied at having seen the town.
Entry.51:
Xmas Day in the workshop indeed. Hullo, and its raining :- However a Happy Xmas to all. These were our greetings to one another. Got up at 8 AM and had breakfast consisting of stew.

Bread & Jam. Cleaned the hut then played Cricket with a board as a bat & tennis Ball. Had two innings, the first innings score was 28-27 the second 38 - 38 so they beat our side by very little. The sun came out at noon. Our Dinner, Had stew, tinned meat, & Bread - Second course :- Bread, cheese, jam. Third Course :-Figs ( dried & preserved ) fruit, and nuts, finishing up with toffee. We all enjoyed it. Played cards the rest of the day. At night we went on picquet but only went to the outskirts of the town, & did guard till 9 PM. Many sailors passed dead drunk and singing their favorite song. The harbour is very fine by night, puts one in mind of Sydney Harbour near Bradley's Head. Came back to camp & turned in. Thus ended my Xmas Day of 1917 :- Shall we see Xmas 1918 on active service is our question today. Hope not
Entry.52: Up at 7.30 AM. Very cold and muddy outside. The camp is very heavy on the feet.The Australians were inspected by SirPercy Cunningham who thought much of the "turn out". After the Inspection we "marched passed" then went on a little route march along a muddy road. had dinner then wrote a few letters. It is very windy. Wrote in the afternoon and fixed photos at night.
Entry.53: Raining during the night so ground is awful. Paid today. Have been writing all the morning. As we are leaving tomorrow, kit bags are being repacked. The Victorians are leaving tonight. Entrained at 5 PM, huddled together like sheep , alot of the windows are broken, so they will have to rough it, as it is raining heavily; with strong wind
Entry.54: Fixed up Kit Bags prior to taking them to the trucks. Entrained at 5 PM when we had tea. There are eight in each carriage. Our party drew the best of the bad lot of carriages. Left Cimino Camp Taranto about 7.30 PM; the night being moonlight we could see the country as we passed through. Olives seem to be the main fruit grown. All land is cultivated. The train is travelling very slowly, being exceedingly long. Passed a few stations, seeming to be shunting alot. Passed through Brindisi about midnight. None of us slept much, the room being inadequate and seats hard. One chap slept on the rack another on the floor. At 6.30 AM we arrived at Bari
Entry.55:
Mess Orderlies went and obtained dry

rations, so we had Breakfast in the train. We stopped near the main Street of this town, and soon had a crowd of people around, selling apples & wine the buildings are the same type in Taranto, the streets are wide and well made. The electric cars are the latest type. Had awalk to keep our feet warm. On the street can be seen women washing, fowls running loose, and goats and donkies roaming around. The carts used, have all large wheels evidently the custom in Italy. This place seems to be the manufacturing centre; wood seems to be used instead of coal, even in the Railway Engines. The morning is lovely, with the warm rays of sun coming in the carriage window. The railway is guarded by soldiers and Military Police. Papers are to be had but none of us can read Italian so they are practically useless.

Stoppped at for Refreshments: Bari, Foggia, Termoli, Fano, Faenza,Voghera and Turin.

Death of man labour is obvious as girls collect the fares on trams and trains. Speaking to an Italian soldier he said he did not like the war. This seems to be the sentiment of all people in South of Italy. They have never heard of Australia nor do they know where it is, so we say we are English going to France. It is now 10AM the town appears to be much busier leaving here we kept to the coast passing the towns of Malfetti, Trani, Barletta and Foggia. At the later place we had dinner and a long looked for wash, and stretch of legs. These towns passed are all of a fair size, having their large buildings and streets. The platforms are low down on the ground, not raised as in Australia. The gauge is 4' - 81/2". Ran into snow about Trani which increased as we went on the fields are covered with it , and

each time it, the train stopped, the lads jumped off and had a snow ball fight, those staying in carriages getting their share. This made everything damp much to the disgust of all afterwards, however it made us warm.

The country is very hilly and every inch is cultivated, on the top of the hills, there is generally an old fort, situated in a predominating position. The sunset was beautiful as it went down over the snow covered hills, with a picturesque village in the valley. Played cards at night til about 8PM then "turned in" one chap perched up on the rack, rather a dangerous and uncomfortable position, Yet he slept more than the others, two more found themselves stretching out on the floor, the remainder took up positions on the lovely cushioned seats. The two "lanks" on one side, the three shorts on the other. I was one of the formers. Had a good sleep till

Sunday the
Entry.56:
1AM when the Orderly sergeant with his sonorous voice cries out "ere two of use chaps go and get dry rations. Not only our compartment but all the train was awake, fancy our temper Tea at 1:30AM is not to be relished,even by hungry soldiers. We stayed at this place about an hour, it is a sea port named Termoli on the main line. Did not sleep much after this. The sea is about four yards from the line, the cross roads are all numbered, generally on the nearest House which are all old and showing signs of ware and tare. The farms are well irrigated being separated by stone hedges and bushes. Household water is obtained from stone wells which have also seen service.

stopped at several stations the following being the chief ones, Loreto, Ancona, Fano, Pesaro Rimini and Faenza. At the former town, is an old castle several hundred years old, still intact, looking very formidable from the height. It is used as an observation station. At these town military uniform predominates the place being under Martial Law. Several trains of returning Italians were passed during the day. The distance between each town is generally four miles, and around each town is the cultivated fields, which are even cultivated onto the railway line. In some of the towns are canals, along which are many fishing craft. A noticeable custom of the people is the waving of their hands. They turn their hand palm up and close and open their fingers. We do this now & get a reply

before, they would not. On the churches they have several Bells which peal their times out to the people, perhaps, now for Centuries. We ran into thick snow. The people dress much the same as in England, the men wear cloaks, the women rarely to be seen with hats on, the poorer class wear shawls. Most of the streets have avenues of trees, of course most streets are barren and desolate and covered with snow at the present. Arrived at Farenza a very large town, Typical of all other towns, has its large public buildings, and churches with its pealing Bells. These seem to get little rest. The streets were covered with snow and slush. The station is a good size. Put equipment on and formed up, leaving for a rest camp. two miles form the train. The streets were practically deserted. Those who watched us pass said in broken English, "Good life & Good Luck" muchly

appreciated by all in the ranks. We had a hot dinner immediately on arrival, having "Tommies" to wait on us, so as to save time. They worked well, having hot water ready to wash our utensils up. we then went to tents and relieved ourselves of equipment, going in for a hot shower, and it was a dinkum hot bath too, this was greeted more so than dinner. Guess how we felt after a good meal and a hot bath, at least like tourists (for thetime) At this camp a good Canteen was well patronized, thus our mess has many good additions in the way of sauce. Jam and other small articles. I spared time to write a little in diary as it is impossible to write on train when it is going. Formed up and received anadditional blanket as would be cold crossing the lower portion of the Alps. Marched back very light hearted, despite the mud and slush which

abounds here. The "Tommies" had cleaned our carriages out so we were good. oh. they didn't lose byit. They think much of the Australians, the men having behaved exceedingly well. This is the first lot to go through Italy. so it is an example to others following. Leaving here we arrived at Bologna about 10PM. This is a junction to Rome & Venice. It is a fine old station having several platforms. These are low down as I have explained, Sentries are all over the station, guarding food stuff etc. The express to Paris came in and out before us. We were issued a foot warmer one to each compartment. so we are set up for the night, much the same order as on the previous night. Slept till about 4AM se we know little of the

country passed. Snow is very thick on the ground. The sun did not come up till about 8 AM on
Entry.57:
When we arrived at Voghera, having hot tea and drawing rations for the day The snow was thick. Had a lovely hot wash, then walked up and down alongside the train, getting exercise and warmth. This town has several factories, and is about the average size of the Italian town, which I should say would be the size of Bathurst. All houses are brick and solid. A British and Italian Hospital train passed us at Voghera. Leaving here with engine on other end we made out for Turon, passing through hilly country, perhaps the most picturesque since leaving. The land, houses, and trees, are thickly covered with snow. Passed over the Rivers Tanaroand Po, The scenery being very pretty.

A few water mills could be seen working bringing us back to older days of history. At Turin the boys had a great snow fight, the snow being frozen. This lasted for over twenty minutes. Although making us wet we were warm after. Had hot tea and dinner here staying in all one hour. it is very cold and frosty. The towns up this way seem deserted very few people being about, most of them can speak broken English. Their language could be easily learnt, if one stayed in Italy a little while. Played cards for a couple of hours. The sun made its appearance for only two hours to day. Turin is a large place having a nice residential part, not seen in previous towns. Looking up a French phrasebook for awhile trying to get a few sentences off. Getting into the Alps now the Maritime Mts. The scenery is splendid, ranges rise

up to the clouds, and the ravines are seemingly thousands of feet below, covered with a good foot of snow, the train travelled round edges of precipitous mountains. However the night came come quickly thus spoiling a more fuller view of this most magnificent scenery of the Southern Portion of the Alps. we crossed the Border of Italy about 11.40 PM and so ended the end of the trip through Picturesque and interesting Italy, incidentally ended the year of 1917, as a closing the majority of people in Italy seem to be against the war and believe England responsible for them being in. In the North of this country however it is different. The New Year found us in France, the country which is fighting for its existance and ours. A new feeling seemed to possess us, for the feeling in this country is different than Italy, and we are proud of France as an Ally
Entry.58:
As the clock showed 12PM the lads awake in the train gave three cheers thus entered the new year. Had a good sleep till about 6AM when we pulled up at Montmelian for Breakfast, and dry stores. Had a wash, the water was cold next to ice. for no sooner was it out of the tap on the ground than it froze. On either side precipitous hills leapt up.covered with thick snow, which dazzles in the sun-light. Passed through country whose splendour cannot be described in words. At the foot of a high mountain the beautiful lake of Aix-Les-Baines lies which winds between the two Ranges with the trains alongside the lake. The tunnel entrance has a castle at each end. Pulled up at Chamberg, here we tried to talk to the French on the station, they do not seem very happy. It is a

large station. Left here running into beautiful scenery unprecedented since starting, followed the River Rhone up to Lyons; it is a beautiful river with mountains rising up from the banks, with fur trees covered with snow and other cultivated areas. A noticeable feature of Agriculture is the way they cultivate up the side of steep hills, which seem to be almost perpendicular. Vineyards are to be seen mostly. Arrived at Lyons about 3 PM the station was deserted, not a single person on it. This seems strange for one of the largest towns of France. The streets are narrow buildings a couple of storeys, old, built of stone and very plain. Electric trams are used. Women do the work in the goods sheds, those pulling carts have dogs tied to the axle, which pull, making

the task much easier. Near the town can be seen Sports Ground which now has thousands of motor cars in, evidently used by the military. Along the banks of river is a beautiful promenade, although now covered with snow and deserted. Pulled out of this city to the next small station by name La Germain, 
El de Mar.

The French towns are not so large as in Italy or so frequent when passing through in the train. Yet this portion of France is not as thickly populated at the Coast & Northern districts. The train that left before us is still here, waiting to go on. Fell In and marched about two miles through thick snow to the camp, which is at the bottom of a steep hill. Allotted to tents, eight in each. Six inches of snow lies on the tents. It is now snowing fairly heavy. Had a hot tea. Not too many availed themselves of the cold water taps. One wash aday is

sufficient these days. We feel it in our feet the most. The tent is now covered with snow from the boots. One good idea on the Railway is the way of changing carriages or trucks to other lines without shunting, they have a slide crossing the lines at Right angles on which 
is
 are two lines the same gauge as the others. A horse pulls the trucks onto this and then pulls the slide across to the line required. Had a walk to Canteen and chatted to some Tommies just from England onto Salonika. They say it is good weather over there, but submarines are busy in channel. Turned in early having a ripping good sleep.
Entry.59:
Up at 7.30 AM and had a breakfast of tea, Biscuits and cheese. It is very cold. They had to heat the drinking water to melt it. Had a walk around the camp to keep feet warm. This is an impossible thing to do



although you have two pairs of socks on.

Fell in at 11Am and marched down to the train, not at all sorry to leave this dismal place with a foot of snow over every inch of it. Train moved off about 1PM and passed over very much of the same kind of country as before. Very little life is to be seen which makes the place more cheerless.

A few people can be seen at the windows. Those who do not venture in the street are in mourning. Plenty of soldiers can be seen. Their uniform is Blue ( Sky Blue ) having a cloak instead of overcoat. The towns are small and far between.

Most of the land is well cultivated. Passed plenty of fur trees which is typical Alpine scenery. The boughs and branches are covered with snow. These trees extend up a steep hills making a very picturesque picture. The houses are old, generally two storey made of brick having their out houses near by. have slate roofs. Came into Moulins about

6PM when tea was issued to all. This is a large town in Centre of France. Have a large Station. In France, the station is on one side with platforms extending out. The platforms are about a foot above the ground. Stayed at this place about an hour. Then moved off. The next station we arrived at of importance was Bourges. However we were all in bed? so did not see much of it. One chap made a blanket of hammocks so we had ample room, every one having a good sleep, till 3AM when the hammock collapsed waking all up especially the chap the occupant fell on. It is not snowing much in this particular part of France.
Entry.60:
Arrived at Tours about 8 AM where we had breakfast, made of Bully Beef heated up in water. Had tea and issued with dry rations. One loaf of Bread to eight men per day so we have to go careful with it. A



train of Americans passed us. they are some "skites" too, about what they will do etc. Very little snow is to be seen about. Tours is a large place, of course little can be seen from the train. It is on the banks of the River Loire which runs into the Bay of Biscay. By the paper it has been 20 Degrees below freezing point at Lyons, so this will give one an idea of the cold. The sun at Tours is already up, so it is much warmer. We are nearing the coast. A lot of the first train missed theirs and had to wait for this train.

Passed over the beautiful river Loire. It is very wide although a good bit is frozen over, some few people were skating on it. Passed through well cultivated land although at present it is unkept. The houses are very few in comparison to Italy. Each house has its garden, most of the plants being covered over with glass bowls protection against the frost

The sun has shone for sometime now. Little snow lies on the ground although the wind is biting. Came into Le Mans a fine large town with modern houses. It is on a tributary of the Loire. Rowing boats and places of amusement can be seen on the banks. In peace it must be a pleasure resort. Has large manufacturing buildings. Several gangs of "Huns" are working on the Railway Lines. They seem in good condition and well clothed. Passed another French Hospital Train loaded with patients. River Sarthe is the tributary mentioned. Buying bread at the stations is the great fun havingto get there before the Officers pull you out. It is 10 aloaf of 2 lbs. Everyone exercises at each stop being cramped up all day. The day is beautiful and clear, the best since leaving Faranto. Along the line a few people gave apples to the men along the train



They are much warmer in their welcome than in Italy. Le Mans station is very fine, one of the best passed through yet. On every church yet passed is a clock and the Railway Stations have their share of them. At this station a clock stands on every platform. Had an hour's stay so had a good walk along the platforms. Bought Bread and Post Cards here. The Paris Express went out, so the boys gave a few sheers to the waves of people in it. Went outside the station alittle and had a look at a couple of streets. They are very narrow and the buildings are old. All people are in mourning. They are very sad and wonder why we are so gay and lighthearted. Some asked for souvenirs and badges. The O.C. of train, a lieutenant of Gallipoli, is an absolute dinkum and perfect gentleman, of course he can get the boys to do anything without asking a second time, and he asks as man to man

We have many privileges which other "stars" would not permit. He came up last night and said "Now lads try & have a shave before getting to Cherbourg as I would like you to look fresh, so as not to make the impression of having had a bad time". Although it was dark nearly everyman set to work with pleasure and had a rough shave in candle light with train going. It is no easy task. Any other officer would have got the reply impossible. This is just an example. It is very cold. The moisture on windows froze. Played cards till 10 PM the turned in.
Entry.61:
Arrived at Cherbourg about 6AM. The train took us into the barracks near the wharf, so did not see anything of the port. Had Breakfast of usual Bully & Bread (one slice) and cold tea. Had a good wash. Although the sun is up

it is very cold on feet and hands. The first train embarked last night for Southampton. We are leaving here about 2 PM. Most of the chaps are satisfied with the trip. Have seen the country, people, habits etc of both Italy & France. Seen the Alpine Districts with it frozen water falls and rivers, the old time water wheels and canals. We all however would have liked to see the towns & villages more, yet that at present is impossible. In all the seven days in the train went far to quickly, all being so absorbed in the picturesque scenery and new country. We had plenty of "tucker" which helped the trip to be successful. We are now looking forward to seeing old England & the eight days leave. Had dinner then embarked on the "Prince George" 900 tons cross-channel steamer 20 knots. The town of Cherbourg

is fairly large having wide streets, and Quays also the quaint French style of Houses. A few people waved goodbye to us from the Quay. Anchored out in stream till dusk then cut over to Southampton, anchoring near Netley. Took five hours to get across the channel was calm. The men slept all over the ship, huddle together like sheep, having no blankets, we put in a cold night.
Entry.62:
Men were very interested in the largest of our ships the "Aquitania" 45,000 tons of hospital ship. Pulled into the docks and waited for a couple of hours before we disembarked. Had coffee & cake then entrained for Salisbury, to the station of Codford. This took about 90 minutes. Band met us and played us into camp a distance of over two miles along a country lane with the old English

hedges on either side. Had dinner then distributed into various training batteries. Most of New South Wales chaps are in No 3 Battery. We are in Isolation for four weeks. Allotted to huts twenty two in each, so we have ample room. A fire is in each hut and we can use it after 4.30 PM each day. Have chaffand five blankets each.
Entry.63: Mess Orderly to day. Reveille at 6.30 AM when horses are watered & fed. Have fairly good Breakfast. Received our kit Bags. So can now have a clean up. It is raining and cold. Wrote letters to put time in.
Entry.64:
Up as usual; went for a two mile route march along a country lane. After breakfast we each took a horse for exercise. Went some three miles along the road. We were medically examined in afternoon after which

we went for another march about another three miles, so we are alittle footsore, and tired. Wrote letters at night and cleaned equipment as we haven't time in morning.
Entry.65:
Freezing cold morning with biting wind. Went for a route march before breakfast. Could not wash as water was frozen in taps. Went for another route march about several miles around two neighbouring villages. they are small but old as the hills, some houses dating 1728. One old town prison is still remaining on the footpath; it is a small round hut capable of holding three people. the churches are very fine old buildings with grave yards around, and the walk under the avenue of trees to the entrance. All land is cultivated well, also irrigated. The little canals are frozen over. At one of these

the boys had great fun sliding over it for half an hour. Many fell much to the fun of spectators. We are all footsore. Issued with heavy boots to break in. Snowing alittle. Allotted to C subsection for training purposes. Sent letter home.
Entry.66:
Went into stables this morning, after breakfast went for short route march, then a Captain gave us a lecture on the various gases. There are five kinds. The latest is known as mustard gas. Causes blisters to come on skin, & you lose your eyesight temporarily. Had Gas Mask Drill for an hour, after which we went into a room and the chlorine was turned on. They made us take our helmets off when in the room awhile. It made us cry or rather tears came in our eyes. Exercised horses all the afternoon



At night wrote letters. It is very cold.
Entry.67: Had to go to Codford to Army Service Corps to load wheat for horses at ourcamp. Came back at 9.30 AM and finished for day. Wrote letters in spare time.
Entry.68: In stables early morning after breakfast exercised horses, taking them eight miles along road. We were very foot sore when coming back, had to do an hour's Physical Culture. they keep us working. At stables in afternoon. Most of us hate this job as the horses are a dash nuisance besides a fiery lot, delight in Kicking. Had a walk to Haftesbury at night then wrote letters. It has been warm today
Entry.69: Did Stables in morning; then had afternoon off, so repacked my kit Bag. At night had a walk into Heytesbury a distance of two miles.
Entry.70:
Had church service at 10 AM when we all enjoyed the service. The Chaplain was modern in his words, also not tiring. The hymns were sung with plenty of volumn. Did horses after the service. In afternoon had a walk along an old English Lane, just wide enough to let two vehicles pass. At one place can be seen the old Toll Gate and House, with the Keepers House close by. A fine view of the surrounding country can be had from a hill near the camp

The land is well cultivated. A few dairy farms are scattered around. Had to do guard from 4 PM till 4 PM Monday.
Entry.71: Snowed heavily during night so guard was not much good. The country has now about six inches of snow over it, making a very pretty scene, with the leafless trees covered with the snow, even to the finest branch. The farms in the distance are covered also the Haystacks. Of course the Australians started snow Balling each other till parade time. When a little wind sprang up the snow on trees fluttered down making a lovely scene. Wrote letters at night.
Entry.72:
Had lectures on different kinds of shells used in 18 pound Field Gun

The most common are shrapnel and High Explosive. The Shells are painted different so as to pick them out. Have an hour's Physical Training each day. Had Gun Drill, and it is a hurry up, having to do it very quickly. You are supposed to be able to load up before the gun comes back to its position from the recoil. Had Lecture on Gunnery. We are now learning alittle. The instructors are very capable.
Entry.73: Stables in the morning. Had knotting and lashing then fuze setting. In afternoon had Gun Drill. and lecture by an officer on France and "Fritz". He put the "wind" up on us alright. Its not healthy over there. Snowed during the day. Isolation has been lifted from today. Wrote letters at night
Entry.74: Went over to Sutton VenyHospital to have a swab taken of throat. Each man has to go over. we however picked a bad day, as had six inches of snow tramp through and pouring rain. Took an hour to get there and another to come back. In afternoon dug trenches on side of a hill. Very wet at finish of day.
Entry.75: Went into Codford for load of oats. Then did stables to dinner. After dinner went in for another load at Codford. Still raining steadily. Finished up at 5 PM. Wrote letters at night. Received a letter from Bob Forsyth.
Entry.76: Had usual Gun Drill and lectures till noon. Wrote letters in afternoon doing stables at 4 PM. Turned in early.
Entry.77: Did stables, then went to church parade, but could not get in; hall being crowded. Came back and cleaned harness. Had afternoon off so cleaned up generally. At night four of us went down to Church of England at Heytesbury. A fine old building dating back to the 15th Century. Crowded with khaki, very few civilians being there. A good service. had a look over it after service, not at all bad Pipe Organ - Went into Institute along road and had supper.
Entry.78: Usual Drill on Guns and shells. On Guard till tomorrow, so there is no news. Raining heavily. Guard stunt no good.
Entry.79:
On guard still till 4 PM when we





were relieved. Wrote letters at night.
Entry.80: Usual Routine, plenty of drill. The weather is quite warm, quite enjoyable when drilling.
Entry.81: No news. A lot have received letters from Australia. Received one from France.
Entry.82: Went to a concert at Y.M.C.A. It was excellent, the Artist being from London.
Entry.83:
Had letters in morning. We are again in Isolation fora month. Have to have our throats sprayed each day. Wrote letters during afternoon and evening. Men we left behind at Suez arrived here today. They came via Genoa; leaving the Alps out of it

From
Entry.85: Os Fernscame over to see me on the
Entry.86:
He is looking good oh. Wrote letters at night, Usual drill all the week, have had a solid training. Weather has been fine although a cold wind is blowing. We were inoculated one day for Para-Typhoid. had twenty four hoursNo Duty, (the best part of it) The 32ndReinfts N.S.W. arrived on Thursday. They came via Genoa. Wrote letters in answer to those received. Have not yet received any Home mail, a good many have.

From
Entry.88:
Received twenty four letters this morning from Aussie. Had a good afternoon reading them. Os Fernscalled

in to see me. He is going on leave on Thursday. received more mail on Wednesday up to
Entry.89:
Usual Drill all the week, plenty to learn. Have had exceptionallygood weather lately. no rain or cold winds.

From
Entry.91:
Went to Warminster on the Saturday with a mate. It is four miles there. A large village, just one street, very narrow and small houses. Walked back so did about ten miles.

On Sunday went over to Sand Hill camp to see Clarrie Brooks. It is a five mile walk. Found him without much difficulty. He looks well & is on a good stunt. getting ready for leave which starts tomorrow.
Entry.92:
Up at 5 AM and had breakfast

Marching off at 6 AM we took the train to London. At Paddington station I left the party who marched to the A.I.F. Headquarters With another chap we went to Euston Station fixing up our passes to go via Holyhead. This took an hour. Then went out to Col Atkinson's Maida Vale, and stayed there. Called on Mrs Martin with Mrs Atkinson. she was pleased to see me. Left by the mail train for Holyhead which arrived at Kingston early in the morning and went up to Dublin a matter of twenty five minutes. Called on my Uncle. He took me over their Guinness's Brewery the largest of its kind
Entry.93:
This Brewery was founded about the Year 1759 and up till 1825 the trade was local, from this date the trade went to England and foreign trade started 1860. The constituants of this beverage consists solely of the following Pale Malt, a certain amount of Roast Malt or Barley to which is due the brown colour of stout, and Hops. The water for brewing purposes comes from the springs which feed the upper level of the Grand Canal, in the Country Kildare. The amount of water used per Year is about 600,000,000 gallons. The first vessels to meet the eye are the Underbacks, designed to hold the sweet liquor known as Wort which percolates through from the vessels, immediately above, and con

stitutes stout in the first stage. By ascending the stairs the Kieve or Mash Tun stage is rearched. These circular vessels, 24 in number and each capable of holding 200 barrels of Malt, are, amongst the most important in the Brewery, for in them the extraction from the malt of the necessary constituents for making stout takes place. The process is briefly as follows:-

The malt, which has been ground the day before into the large Hoppers above the Mash Tuns is let down gradually at an early hour in the morning through the slide at the base of the Hoppers into cylinders, which command the Mash Tun. Here it is met by a stream of hot water ascending. Inside the cylinder are rakes that revolve at a High

speed and mix malt and water together. Inside the Mash Tunis another set of rakes, which travels round the edge of the vessel by means of a rack and wheels, for the purpose of further mixing. The liquor is then drawn off through the slotted plates forming the false floor of the Mash Tuninto the Underbacks beneath. By this time the constituents soluble in water & necessary for the manufacture of stout have been extracted. This is then pumped into twelve fermenting tunseach holding 1400 barrels. Yeast is added to excite the necessary fermentation, which takes two days; the wort is pumped to open vessels for the purpose of cooling, and also for the skimming-off of the yeast, which reproduces itself about 15 times

When the yeast is off, it is pumped to huge vats, each having 1/2 mile of iron hoop around it, holding 1700 Hogshead ( 52 gallons ) About 4000 people are employed.

Leaving this very interesting place we went around the centre of city.The main streets and buildings are very fine of course Sackville Street near the Post Office is in ruins, caused by the Rebellion a year ago. The electric service of trams (double deckers) is excellent. Went to a theatre at night. The city lighting is not restricted as in London so it is a pleasure getting around at night. Stayed with Uncle till morning when I caught the 9 AM train to the North . The population of Dublin is about

a half million. There is no food restrictions, and food is plentiful. The Railway Stations are fine large places, and the train services are very good. I was sorry that I only had a day in this place, but hope to get there again.
Entry.94:
The train journey up took four hours. Kept along the coast as far as Dundalk, when we changed and went inland. The country has had too much rain, the land being covered with water, so ploughing is delayed. My Uncle Charlie met me at the station and we went up to the House in the Jaunting Cart

Had a look around the House & land. Much the same as when I was there last time. A good deal

of the land is ploughed. Both Aunt & Uncle are looking well. Had a good sleep at night as you can imagine.
Entry.95:
Went to church with A & U. The driver of the Jaunting Cart was dressed up to kill, in a uniform of navy serge and swank buttons. (The pity is the photo is no good).

The church is a fine old church capable of holding the population of Dromore twice over. The minister was awful. Uncle went to 
church
sleep in church. Have good fires in the church. Grandfather is buried in the yard adjoining church.

In afternoon received Australian letters sent from camp. So spent a good afternoon reading them
Entry.96: Uncle and self had arranged to go out Snipe shooting all day , but it poured raining throughout the whole day. so did little. Shot a few pigeons which came up close to the house. Had game of Deck Quoits and put in time generally.I like this way of just doing as you like and plenty of time to do it in. Copied dates concerning family out of old Bible used some years ago by Grandfather. Also took a copy of the Hamilton Crest. At night we played the game of 500 till late. They like this game.
Entry.97:
Very cold, there being a frost on the ground. Clear day; very nice in sun. With Uncle & Aunt we walked into the town, about four

miles, along the country road. Had a fine view of District around Dromore from the hills. Every inch of ground is cultivated and the farmers are busily plowing and heavy work it is too. There are numerous small lakes. Met an old school mateof my father's who was exceedingly glad to see me. He is a typical Orangeman, by name George Donnell. Remembers many instances of young days. Still has a flute my father gave him when he was leaving "Lakemount". Dromore has a population of 476 people and consists of about four streets of old houses, majority in decayed condition. Had a look over Uncle Jim's garden, then took photo of old church, which my

Grandfather attended when a boy. It is now in ruins. Saw the Marshall boys (?). Walked back for dinner. It is a lovely day. In afternoon went out rabbit shooting, but did not get one. Saw another school mate of Dad's, Robt Coulter by name is a tenant
s
of Uncle's. Another staunch Ulsterman. Thinks I'm like "Master Robert". Uncle Jim came up for dinner, after which we played four hand 500, till about midnight. Uncle Jim & I lost by one game - Uncle Charlie likes winning.
Entry.98:
Fixed up Aunt's Bicycle putting protector 
of
 over back wheel. Rather a long job. Received more letters. Had a walk around the House

and garden taking a few snaps. The garden is just beginning to show signs of coming out. For this year the winter is over early. Had late dinner, then walked leisurely down to the station. The rain again wept at my departing. I'm evidently a Jonah for the rain has come down on the both occasions I have been there. Arrived at Dublin about 8 PM when we took the boat over to Holyhead. The ship was just packed with soldiers on the way to France after leave in Ireland. The sea was calm; night moonlight so 
though
 tin fish might prowl about. However we arrive safely at the port
Entry.99:
6AM found me at Euston Station so went to Hotel and had a bath and breakfast. After this strolled round in search of a Kodak's place. Took a bus & had a glance at a few main places of London, then called in at Commonwealth Bank. At noon found me at Col Atkinson's.

Went for a walk around Maida Vale with the Colonel. This use to the the residential su
r
burb of London once, But now the fine large Houses are practically in ruins. The Streets are wide. A canal runs through the district this is strange being so near to the city of London. Stayed here till 6PM when I had to leave for the train to camp, arriving at this

cheerless place about 11 PM. And so ended my Irish Leave and to say the least I wish it had been 80 days. If by chance a few days happen my way prior to going over I am sure Dublin will have them.
Entry.101: Had the old gun drill etc again the remainder of Reinforcements are not going on leave for another week. Dom Johnson is in
Entry.102: Battery, so had a chat with him. He is warmedfor draft.
Entry.104:
On Sunday Dom Johnson & self went over to see Clarrie Brooks at Sandhill Camp. had a fine old talk. Came back at 8 PM
