It is about 90 minutes walk back. Met an old friend from Water Board Ern Pullen, who was wounded, and now about to hop over again. Had quite a long talk to him of days gone.

Am in the Layers class, about twelve of the best layers in the group picked out. it is interesting work. the remainder of Reinforcements went on leave on Thursday, so our Hut is practically deserted, there being only nine left. "Chips" Wood a mate of mine contracted measles, so our Hut is now isolated. we are a happy family, have all meals in the Hut and plenty of it, in fact too much for we often wish to have a sleep in the afternoon. The boys when they come back from leave will just roar, having to leave the old

Hut till isolation is lifted. The windy weather came in time for on the
Entry.105: March, the wind was terrific and cold. All did a freeze. The older chaps feel it acutely. It goes through the strongest of us. A little snow fell. It is a belated winter alright. The green leaves are just showing life, so in a month the hedges should be very picturesque.
Entry.108:
and today I have reached my majority. Received mail from Home which was eagerly read. They are the best presents one could get.

Os Fernscame over in the afternoon so had a good long talk of our leave. He had an excellent time in England and looks well. The cold winds are still blowing. They seem perpetual

Wrote letters Home at night. On Monday , Tuesday & Wednesday mornings we had to go to Sutton Venyto have throat sprayed. There are about five hundred in Isolation. It is a six mile walk, so just cuts out the morning. The wind is still fierce and cold, almost unbearable. Passed out Gunnery on Thursday & on Friday morning warmed for draft; some eight hundred in all the Brigade going. Went to Warminster on Saturday & met Os Ferns, both had our photo taken Developed three spools at night. of the Gas test with the Guns. They turned out good. Have been busy with Q.M. Store getting fresh issue of clothing etc. Had Gas Drill with Helmets; they take getting use to
Entry.110: At Q.M. Store all morning returning old issue of clothing. Sent Camera to London. It was like parting with an old friend having had it for two years. Today has been glorious a typical Australian Day with beautiful sun. Passed out as Gun Layer on Monday. Had an easy test, as we have not had the training. On Tuesday, packed up ready to leave the following morning. About five hundred are leaving. We are taking little Kit with us. Just a change of clothing and socks, with one blanket.
Entry.111:
"Reveille" at 6 AM we cleaned up our huts and had an early breakfast. The usual hustle of men getting things they had omitted to put in Kit etc.

the previous night prevailed. However this soon stopped with the bugle sounding the Fall In. Rolls were called & rechecked, and at 9 AM we moved off to Codford. After receiving light refreshments from Y.M.C.A we entrained arriving at Southampton near 1 PM, immediately embarking on a small cross-channel steamer by name "Queen Alexandria", a fast boat, much to our delight. Had a fair amount of room on her considering, and all our "clique" had a good sleep, although the life belts were a little hard. Le Havre the Australian Base for reinforcements was reached about midnight, about seven hours run only.
Entry.112:
Le Harve has a fine harbour, and an immense shipping trade. There are several locks. The town from





the distance seems very large, and has the typical French Houses. Disembarked about 6 AM and walked through the outskirts of town. It seems very dirty. Have numerous Hun Gangs working on wharves. They are in good condition. Arrived at our camp about 11.30 AM, a little tired. It is beautiful weather. The camp is situated on a steep hill overlooking Harfleur a small town near Le Havre. Have fourteen in each tent so things are a little congested. Issued with "Tin Hat", waterproof cape etc; Then went through the usual Medical Inspection. At night an American Concert Party entertained the troops at the Y.M.C.A. Hut. They were exceedingly good. The Huts here are very spacious. and have all that one needs.
Entry.113: "Reveille" at 6.30 AM. They have daylight saving here. Had an early breakfast then the whole reinforcement went about 2 miles to the Gas School. Had to wear our tin Hats. They are alittle heavy to begin with. Had lectures and practical work all day, also our Gas Helmets tested. The weather is still fine. The food here is plentiful and good. Put the night in at the Pictures.
Entry.114: Put in the day fixing up for going up the line. A lot of the 31st chaps are on draft. so they have separated very well, much to our disgust. Wrote a few letters in afternoon. It is lovely weather, very warm in sun. A few had leave to Le Harve. Pictures again attracted us.
Entry.115: Detail for guard, so set to work to clean equipment, as best dressed man gets off duty, and has an afternoon pass to town. My luck was in and I won the prize. About two hundred of the Boys left early this morning for up the line. Wrote letters and went to church at night the C of E chap is High Church, & the lads do not like it. Old Mac who is a Pres felt out of place.
Entry.116:
Detailed to our divisions this morning. Pinkerton, Mac & myself are in the fourth Division. have been lucky sticking together so long - Had a Special church service prior to leaving as we go in morning. Went on leave to Le Harve by myself. It is about 30 minutes in

train to the town. Picked up with an infantry chap so we had alook around together. The town is large, has very few fine buildings, fine large streets, but filthy. There seems to be plenty of business doing. The shipping trade is immense, there being a fine harbour. The tides are large. The Quay is a fine portion of the town. Food is not too plentiful. Arrived home early and packed up Kit, preparatory to leaving in morning.
Entry.117:
"Reveille" at 5 AM when we had some food. Fell In about 6.30 AM, packed up, so that we could scarcely move. Moved off about 8 AM on the long march to Le Harve about seven miles. We had many

rests as our Kit naturally became heavier. A Tommy Band played us in most of the way.Arrived in the town about 11.30AM, hot and illtempered. Allotted to trucks, about twenty five in each, so have a good number to Keep the truck warm. The greater part of train is occupied by Americans. They are a fine type of man, although they swank alittle. Moved off about 1PM and were lucky in getting through so quickly. The country up this way is in good condition, and well cultivated. Played cards to pass time away. Rained most of time. Pulled up for hot water about dark. All turned in about 6PM the best way possible, and awoke at 8 AM on the
Entry.118:
not alittle fresh. However had

an impromptu wash near a railway station. Arrived at Hazelbrouck a fairly large town about 11 AM, when we detrained, and went to a Rest Camp. This camp is a billet in a large House, that has been destroyed by shells. Had all conveniences however, so we all enjoyed a shave and a wash. A few of us went into town and had a feed. This town has been shelled for the last few days and the people have the " Wind up" and have left for healthier regions. The Town square is fine. The buildings are all old and poor looking. The Cathedral seem to get all the money, for they are beautiful beyond imagination. Leaving here we got another train and went about twenty miles further North to Bailleul where

we reported to a base. Had tea then went into town. This place is much like previous town stopped at. Has a large square, with principal buildings around it. A good many have been destroyed by shell fire. Our Huts are protected up to about three feet with sand against bombs. Did not sleep much owing to noise of our guns. An occasional Hun shell came dangerously near, although the town received a good number.
Entry.119:
Had Gas masks tested, then with full kit set out to find the 4th P.A.C's Headquarters. Some chaps were lucky and received alift when near the town, However about twenty of us were unlucky, so had to tramp about eight miles, in Hot

sun. Went through Loere near the border of France & Belgium, Near here the Huns put a few shells over us, and made us feel uneasy. Took turns at carrying the Kits which did not g on waggon. Arrived at the Headquarters and had dinner. The Colonel then asked us particulars and let mates keep together, and to go to same Brigade. He was very good to us. A guide took us to the No1 Section of A.D.A.C., where I was put in "D" Sub Section with "Mac" & "Pink" Having only one blanket we were very cold at night.
Entry.120:
"Reveille" went at 6.30 AM when the Horses & "Donks" were watered & fed. the latter are proper "dopes" and hated by all. Feltthey do good work and are hardy and strong workers

about ten of us had to go to a dump to load 4o5" shells. A "G? Waggon took us out, the distance being about six miles, through Kemmel, which has and is being shelled fairly heavily. The church spirebuilding is in ruin. Had to load Gas Shells onto trucks and bring them up to the main line about five hundred yards. Had sport coming back on trucks, like a scenic way, only a few 9.2" Hun shells made things alittle uneasy, particularly when we were at the shell dump. All shells went into Kemmel. Had to load up 1250 cases which took us to 1030 PM to do. Our hands were cut & sore, and majority agreed that it was the hardest days work they had ever done. Luckily a waggon took us home, and a rough trip at that.
Entry.121: Did not get up for first parade. Knocked about stables all the morning. After dinner received orders to leave this position, as division was drawing out. This meant Hustle. Made up the feeds for the sub & fed the Donks & watered, Packed our Kit and put them on the Limbers & waggons. I am detailed to stay back to load up the ammunition. The Section pulled out about 6PM. Had a good nights sleep. Up at 4.30AM & packed about seven "GS" Waggons. Left the camp about 6AM on.
Entry.122:
We jumped up on waggons. It is a beautiful morning. Just lovely bathing in the sun. The foliage is just coming out and the crops peeping up above the ground. The people are going to

church. The 1st Division are taking our position. Could not go through Bailleul owing to bombardment of same. this meant several extra miles journey round. Passed through several villages. The old Houses are very quiet and old. Yet they are fascinating, with old thatch roof, water mill and barn. Most of Houses are painted white. The people are Flemish. Passed border about 7 AM. The roads are rough. Arrived up to the Battery about noon and had dinner. Fritz had shelled this camp the day previous. when the first division left at about 2PM and it indeed formed a long line stretching along the roads for a great distance. Passed many villages, the people keep the sabbath here, & appear to be great church goers.

The interior of churches are wonderful. I was on a waggon as brakesman, a good job, for you can sit down. Passed through a large town about dusk named Merville; Pitched camp at a Billet about a mile out.

Watered and fed the "Donks", then had a well earned hot meal. Billeted in Farm Houses and barns. Several of us slept under a "G S" Waggon, with plenty of Hay to keep us warm. This is my first night of Roughing it.
Entry.123:
Started out again on our journey at 9 AM after the usual waiting. The weather is perfect so the travelling is not so hard. This part of country is in good condition, the crops just coming up. Rode a mule and led a lame mare all day. We are at the end of the column, with the spare horses.

Passed through many large towns, most of which have signs of the war on them. At dusk we entered Houdain, and camped there the night. We were Billeted in a Estaminet( Hotel ) all the sub section. The whole D.A.C. were in various houses. Had a good sleep.
Entry.124:
On the road again at 8.30 AM, the roads are crowded with English Artillery and French people who are leaving for safer towns. You could see, the farm carts, packed with Mattresses; with oats or Hay, driven by an elderly man far too old to do such work, the cattle following the cart, kept together by a feeble old lady or perhaps daughter of the old chap, the children sitting in the cart looking down at the traffic & so all through the Hot day & dust this goes on, an endless chain of

war material going to different places in the line. After a hard days travelling we pulled into an open paddock for the night at Saulty
.
Had tea, then made a bed out of Hay in the open. Slept well being tired.
Entry.125:
Moved out early in morning on the track, and went through villages now deserted by the inhabitants, asthese places are frequently shelled day and night coming through the small village, a Hun came over in one of our planes dropping three bombs, which landed about ten yards from the road, blowing a few off their horses. The road was soon cleared. This gave us alittle "Wind Up". Pulled into a field with crops just coming up but now deserted by the farmer, for the Huns are very near, and you can see our large guns firing. They

made a great row, more so than the Hun shells exploding. Had to sleep out in open. I Being on guard had a position under a limber.
Entry.126:
Pulled out early, and at noon arrived at Warloy, where our guns are in position. The large guns are near the road & make a Great noise & flash. The mules are fairly steady under fire.

Put into a farm house for two hours then went down the road alittle way. Detailed to go with the limbers up to the guns, so left about 2PM going through Warloy and made up to the line, passing many Batteries of Heavy guns, and going through Henencoast, arrived at the Batteries which are in action open warfare position on a side of a hill, thus very exposed to the Huns, who can

see you coming over the Hill. The drivers make the old tired mules travel over it too. This town has been shelled considerably, and has several Hospitals in it. Just a clearing station. You can see for miles away from the Hill, all ploughed & crops up on land, and at present few shell holes. Came back to village, then had to go to a dump for ammunition, but they had none so turned into a aerodrome and it was a welcomed rest, as it had rained for a few hours, & everyone was wet through. The mules were exhausted. Had huts to sleep in,so we were lucky.
Entry.127:
On Stable picquet all say, so had an easy day and a chance to dry clothes. The teams went out for ammunition and came back about noon, so

the "Donks" had a well deserved spell. Turned in early as we have to leave this home, and report back to the village. Wrote a few letters. Killed a heifer, so had extra meat.
Entry.128:
Still wet. On same job as yesterday. nothing much to do. Teams went out after dinner to Battery I remained behind to go with a General Service Waggon to the village so am lucky being out of rain. The "Heavies" around us, are pouring the shells into the Huns. Arrived at the village of Contary where the remainder are camped. This place is practically under water, so it is hard dirty work, feeding the mules etc, and doing other numerous fatigues. Found a Billet in a loft of a large barn, so we are out of rain luckily. The Chateau

is a fine building with beautiful grounds. Has a large stream running through it. The owners have left it in a hurry for the place is just as it was left. The fellows helped themselves to the cellar & some had more than their share. At night we made a fire in loft and had several extra articles to eat, for the canteen has at last come to light. Our bread ration is very small, so the Army Biscuits are sort after very eagerly. Had a good sleep after travelling so much. How long we will stay here is the vital question.
Entry.129:
"Reveille" went about 7 AM so we are not feeling too bad. Owing to muddy fields we just fed up. After breakfast the animals were let loose in an adjoining field to graze. They acted like school children just "breaking up" for Xmas Holidays, the antics of some

were humorous. The day has cleared alittle. They have given us a half day off owing, I suppose to it being Easter Sunday, yet to us, it is hard to distinguish one day from another. The Hun put a couple over in the village at dinner time so has the right range. This will mean, we will have to evacuate to another position. From the hill you can see Albert and our shells bursting. The 3rd Division did good work yesterday and captured 3000 huns. The latter were surprised to see the Australians down here, thinking that they were at Ypres still. Wrote a few letters but cannot post them. as they have no time to censor them.
Entry.130:
Not raining so much now. Grooming mules till 10 AM when all the new hands had to pack up and

start out to the Australian Dump at Contay. About fourteen of us; put our Kits in the waggon, so just had a nice walk of about two miles to the dump. During the afternoon we packed up shrapnel and H.E., & at the finish had sore hands & weary limbs. Fritz put a few shells over in close proximity to us 50 % being "Duds" owing to soft ground. Had a read at night and received four letters, first since being up here.
Entry.131:
Up at 8 AM and started on the Dump. Had breakfast then worked solid till lunch. Our meals, however are not sufficient for the Hard work we have to do, but of course cannot complain. How often we wish for half the luck to Have a good meal in Sydney and a big look at the old familiar

streets. Had a wash today so at last look alittle like myself again. This part of front seems too quiet to last. Had a look over a couple of tanks just ready to go up. They are much smaller than original tanks, but do twelve miles per Hour having two .45 Horse power machines. They Hold three men and driver having four machine guns in them. They are used in open country for they are not climbers like the larger tank. It is lovely weather again.
Entry.132: Sorting out the Dump still. Have H.E. on one side and shrapnel on the other. Alot of Gas 4.5 came in. It is hard work but we like being away from the Section. Fritz generally sends presents over each day at the same time, & in the same spot.
Entry.133:
On the dump as usual. Much ammunition is being taken out. This sector of Line had a "stunt"

and held Fritz back successfully, although they suffered many casualties. The Artillery also received many casualties to both men & horses.
Entry.134: Getting all the empty cases packed up. At night went on guard and was kept busy with numerous waggons coming forshells. About 40,000 shells were taken in the two days.
Entry.135:
On guard during the day. Still taking the ammunition away, as I believe we are going over the top tomorrow. At 4 PM we were all warned to go back to our sector, which we did. We then received two days rations &

reported to Divisional Headquarters about half a mile away. Here we received letters and my luck was in for I received four letters from home and of a late date (20 Feb). They came C/o Col Atkinson. 
At
this place we were sent to Batteries, so by wording the W.O. he let mates keep together so Pink & I are in the 39th Battery 10th Brigade. Four others 31st Reinfts men are in it too. Reported to the waggon line near tea time & billeted in a Barn. It is not far the D.A.C and about 6 kilometres from the Battery.
Entry.136:
Exempted from early morning parade so had an extra Hour's sleep. The food is not too bad for up here. attached to "E" Sub temporarily, so groomed

a "Donk" each. They are not very regimental here, so it is goodo. A Corporal runs it, so we have a good time. The weather is lovely plenty of sun. A couple of shrapnel shells burst over the Horse lines, but no harm was done. A horse was killed yesterday, and a few wounded.
Entry.137:
Up at 6.30 AM but had little to do before breakfast. The ground is now soft and walking is very heavy also socks & boots are saturated. Packed our Kit and moved to a new billet about five hundred yards up. Had to move all personnel, so had plenty to do. At the end of one of these " perfect Days" we were tired, wet & covered in mud, "Somme Mud" at that. We are now in a barn, guaranteed not to leak?

Received another letter from Bess. Also photo of family. The 2nd Division are coming up this way.
Entry.138: We are situated at Behencourt a small village. Cleaned harness alittle and had an easy day altogether. Wrote a few letters at night.
Entry.139:
Cleaned the lines up a little. After tea, looked Will Chapple up at the next village for

his Battery is Billeted there. He looks well. All the Australian Divisions are up this way now, so may see others I know. The forward Waggon Line came down here tonight owing to them having such a strenuous time standing to.

Thursday
Entry.140:
Washed a couple of Waggons down at the creek near by. There are many

streams about this district, and are used for driving the water mills. Fritz has left us alone for some time now. It is very quiet here.
Entry.141: A beautiful day to day real typical Australian weather, having little to do, we enjoyed sitting out in it. Had a game of football at night.
Entry.142: Extremely cold and windy, so did little work. You can see by the last few days we are having an easy time. Much traffic is passing at night. Fritz came over in a number of Gothas, Passing over head. They went through a Barrage of shrapnel and Lewis Gun fires, without a mishap. It is a lucky shot that hits a vital spot. They made towards Amiens, at present a great attraction for Fritz.
Entry.143: Did little work this morning, & in afternoon had a holiday till 4 PM. Being extremelycold we kept the fire in the Barn warm. Wrote a couple of letters. A couple of planes came over but did no damage.
Entry.144: Washed waggons most of the day. After 5 PM we strolled down to D.A.C. to see some of the 31st Reinfts who are at present attached there. Had alittle luck at the Canteen also.
Entry.145:
Went for a bath today. First since Le Havre, over a month ago. We all enjoyed it immensely as you may guess. Hardly knew each other after it. They give you a clean change of clothes if you want them, the chats still stay in there however. The Gun teams had stiff

luck, for Fritz put over about twenty 4.2" H.E speculators, and they landed in the Horse lines, Killing two men & wounding seven, also several mules were killed.
Entry.146: Doing odd jobs around the Barns and cleaning up a waggon. It is a perfect Home here, and has lasted longer than I had anticipated. Howevererelong we will come a cropper & will go up to the pits. Received two letters from Aussie today.
Entry.147: Received ten Australian letters so was busy reading them, getting all the latest news. Did usual camp fatigues, which are very few and petty, so find the days occupied in telling yarns ortalking of the present situation. Rumours are very numerous about here
Entry.148: Washed and oiled limbers all day. The weather is now alittle warmer, and shows signs of clearing up.
Entry.149: Cleaned harness etc till dinner. then detailed to go up to the Headquarters of Battery with three others. Rode a horse each so the four kilos or more were soon left behind. Reported to C.O. and found our job to be a guard over ammunition in our reserved position pits. between Henencourt & Baijeux. Went back to the forward waggon lines, having tea & leaving our Horses there. Fixed up a dugout near the dump and salvaged a few blankets, Did guard in our turn, but did not have much sleep owing to fierce barrages of a six inch Battery alongside, also the nerve racking sound of the Huns shells wailing overhead & the
Entry.150: inevitable explosion. Several came too near throwing debris onto road. Needless to say we Kept our "Headsdown". Had meals at the Battery so we were lucky, for our rations were down at our lines. In the afternoon Fritz put a few salvos over near us, and two 4.2" shells landed on the road alongside our dugout, wounding two of the party severely. One went into a chaps left lung & he was just pretty near finished. I bandaged up the other fellow who got a good Aussie, getting it in the groin & knee. Luckily an ambulance was passing so they took them to the Dressing Station. We left here for our natural and got our horses, reporting back to our waggon lines. "We didn't arf go" as a Tommy would say.
Entry.151: Did usual camp fatigues. Weather is now much milder Received a couple of letters.
Entry.152: Cleaned and oiled a few waggons There is very little work to do. At night I generally write or have a strole down the village. Turn in pretty early.
Entry.153:
Stableman today, so had a read most of the day. Wrote letters at night.

Thursday
Entry.154: Oiled a few limbers. In afternoon the lads took a half holiday but the Capt gave it to us half an hour afterwards. Wrote letters & chatting in the sun is a necessary work on half-holidays
Entry.155: Jack Jacobs came up to see me at night, so we had a long talk together. he is getting into same Battery. Received a few snaps from England, taken while at Heftsbury camp. They have turned out well.
Entry.156:
Detailed with four other chaps to relieve up at the guns. Not sorry in away, as the Major & B.S Major have made waggon lines regimental. Am attached to E Sub, the same as Pinkerton. Have a good dug out, there are four of us. the Corporal is very decent. At ten we had to unload ammunition. Up at 4AM with the No1. Fired twelve salvos onto one target. I set the fuses and loaded. Finishing this we fired fourteen H.E at another target. He let me fire these off, so was delighted to have had a shot at the Huns.

the gun makes some noise and flash. Have to block your ears. Finishing the shoot we "stood to" til 6AM. When we again turned into bed.
Entry.157: Had breakfast in bed. Afterwards took a few shells over to the gun. In afternoon had a sleep. On guard at night and was lucky in drawing first shift. It is an S.O.S guard. have to watch for the signal from our Sector. Guns did a shoot at 8:30PM till 10PM. Had a good sleep till morning.
Entry.158: Got the breakfast forthe sub, which stayed in bed till 12:30PM, as the day was wet & windy. The mud is awful .Our cook house is in the village some distance from the guns. It is unhealthy in any village. This is no exception to Fritz shells.
Entry.159: Sleeping is the chief item here, as we do all the shooting at night, generally from 8.30PM till 11PM. Last night we sent over a few good rounds. I am now an expert at firing. The weather is very dull, and ground muddy.
Entry.160:
Had breakfast in bed. It is very cold and windy. Got up at 11.AM and packed our Kits as we are pulling out from the position tonight, being relieved by the Tommy Artillery. Handing over cancelled for twenty four hours, owing to traffic on the road, as Infantry are changing over. The Tommy officer who us taking over from us, came this afternoon. A typical pictured officer with unnatural speech, binocle to eye, and a poor horseman, would not even ride down a four foot

bank onto road, but went down some yards onto same level as road. One of the boys said, he was going to sleep in his boots tonight as the Tommies were holding the front line. This gives you the general idea of what "Aussie" thinks of his English friend as a fighter. Our Infantry have asked for the A.F.A. to be allowed to cover then in the new positions taken up.
Entry.161: It is a lovely day; plenty of sunshine, none of us woke up till 10.30 AM, so missed breakfast. However we were in time for dinner. We are not moving out till tomorrow now, orders having again been altered. Wrote a couple of letters Home.
Entry.162:
Up at noon and packed our gear for moving out. It was a lovely day

Pulled our guns out at 8.30 PM the Tommies taking over the position. Had to walk to the Rear Waggon Lines. Had a lift apart of way. Pulled out from here and travelled all night Keeping in close touch to the Line. Rain came down to torrents making things just anyhow for everyone. The darkness was intense.
Entry.163:
Arrived outside Amiens about 5 AM and could see the city also the fine Cathedral which stands out prominently against the city. we pitched camp outside Amiens, having breakfast. The position being too exposed we moved out soon after to a bank near the railway line. Here we made dug outs & horse lines. being very tired we all



slept anywhere till dinner. The Heavies are very busy in this sector. Made a dug out large enough for the five of us, but owing to the shortness of light we could not make it waterproof. went to bed with the sky very clear, but at 2AM we were washed out, so had a wet time till "Reveille"
Entry.164: Did usual work in horse lines till dinner time. Fortunately the sun came out, so we dried our blankets & clothes. also made our dugout seaworthy. Had a good sleep at night.
Entry.165:
The Major is swinging "his weight around" and makes the days work extend from 6.30AM till 5.30PM, also extra duties to do at night. The men are up against it but can do nothing. He is certainly a poor specimen of a man. Received

ten Australian letters today, so feel contented. Was on guard from 10PM till 2AM

Tuesday
Entry.166: Cleaned the horse lines out and put in time generally. After parades we went into the River Somme which is only a hundred yards away for a swim. It was lovely. A few "Aussies" had salvaged rowing boats, and you could see them merrily going down stream as it it was at National Park or any other pleasure resort. The country around is very picturesque, and these lovely warm days, makes you wish to be back home to our local pleasure grounds.
Entry.167:
Made a Bomb proof shelter around the horses, owing to the Gothas liking this spot. particularly the railway nearby. He dropped four bombs this afternoon

about four hundred yards away on the "points". The French Naval guns near by had a premature burst which Killed a few men in the 110th Horse lines. They are nine inch guns.
Entry.168: Took horses grazing till dinner time. In afternoon with two others I went to Brigade Headquarters with remounts. Going Along the road a Naval Gun of Fritz's fired the shell landing in close proximity to us. Of course we went as fast as the Horses would go and having no saddle on, made us pretty tired. It is a lovely day, quite warm.
Entry.169: Clean up stables in morning in afternoon went swimming in the River for an hour. It was alittle cold but enjoyed it thoroughly. Wrote a few letters
Entry.170: Had half holiday on account of the Battery Sports which were held in the afternoon. The chief items were tug of war on Horse back when many strenuous goes were witnessed, Cock fighting on horse back, not the least amusing was the Donks High jump. Some of these intelligent brutes managed their two front feet over and there stayed. However an E Sub Donk named "Aussie" won by jumping near four feet. a good height for a mule with no practice. The Sports ended up with a "Donks" race; the field being two large to pick out a favorite. It was a pleasant break from camp routine and all enjoyed it.
Entry.171:
Guns went into action near Villiers - Brettoniaux at 2 PM, I did not go up with our gun, but

will be on next relief. There is plenty of work down at Waggon Lines to Keep you going all day. Fritz came over at night, and dropped two bombs near by. We rebuilt our dug out, making a general improvement on it. Worked hard today so enjoyed a good sleep till Reveille, of
Entry.172: When all horses were watered. The stream is only a few yards away yet we have to go around about three quarters of a kilometre to it, as a reserve trench is in between & barbed wire entanglements. Rain came on in afternoon making things dismal for all.
Entry.173:
Beautiful sunny weather which we all enjoy. Have left off wearing woollen goods now. In the afternoon the River

Somme is well patronised by all.
Entry.174: Made the Bomb proof shelter higher but the weather is too hot to work, so we enjoy sitting down, having a sun bask. Had a swim in the evening The teams went up to the guns with ammunition at night. The Guns are in good position I believe, although Fritz has put a few "Heavies" amongst them
Entry.175: Fritz is very busy in the air and kept us awake a good part of night. He dropped a large number of Bombs around us. The Heavies too came dangerously close to our lines. It is perfect weather.
Entry.176:
Had the usual work to do in Horse Lines, in afternoon went down for



a swim and met Major Holmes A. Court and Major Kennedy in swimming. I was very pleased to see the former as he is such a good fellow. He was on the " Karooka" as Adjutant. Had a talk for a good time the swimming was good not too cold.
Entry.177: Beautiful Hot weather , much like an Australian summer day. Have to do Mounted Orderly for Brigade today. Reported over to the 37th Battery and stayed for twenty four hours. had two small trips during that period.
Entry.178: Half holiday; so went down for a swim with the boys. It was lovely in. Wrote a few letters at night and played a game of cricket with improvised bat and ball. A tin Hat was the wicket.
Entry.179: Cleaned the lines up generally, In afternoon had my boots mended, on the "While You Wait" system having no others to out on. This took all the afternoon. Had a swim at night.
Entry.180: "Reveille" went at 2.45AM when we had to "stand to" as word had come down that Fritz would hop over most likely about dawn. Harnessed all teams in readiness to "tootsweet" if he came. However the "Barrage" put up by our guns, evidently made him change his mind, so we watered our horses about 5AM, cleaned the Lines and had Breakfast. In afternoon we had a few hours off so all went in for a swim till 4PM. It was glorious in a lovely out. The weather is perfect; a cool breeze makes the warmth of sun pleasant.
Entry.181: Took a couple of horses out grazing in the morning and had a sleep. In the afternoon cleaned up the Horse Lines; finishing up with a swim in the river.
Entry.182: Did the usual camp fatigues and at night wrote a few letters. This sector is very quiet today.He only put over two shells near by. Wrote a couple of letters The weather has changed a little to the cool side.
Entry.183: Did the same camp fatigues, & built up the Bomb Proof around the Horses. This sector is very quiet today. We are getting a new kind of glass eye pieces in our Gas Mask Supposed not to smear.
Entry.184:
Had a half holiday in the morning so put the time in reading. At dusk, three of us went about a kilo down the railway to a large deserted vegetaable garden, and salvaged a bag of Lettuces & Eschallots After doing this we had an interesting half hour looking at a French soldat catching frogs. He has a rod and tackle, with four small hooks at the end, and on the end of the line a light peeble which he skips across the pond. The frog seeing this moving immediately followes and when on top of the hooks he pulls the rod back, catching the frog easily. For the time being he puts it on a wire with the others already caught. When the frogs are on the surface of pond a lead weight is substituted for other peeble. He then adopts the method

of dropping the weight alongside the frog, submerging the hooks under the frog. A quick pull up does the deed. They only eat the Hind legs which are fried. The frogs appear to be of the usual size & Species to those in Australia. At night our guns gave the Hun a fierce bombardment lasting over two Hours. The weather is misty
Entry.185: Did the usual work in stables. Had the afternoon off, so wrote a fewletters. The weather is changeable.
Entry.186:
Cleaned the limbersup, and had an easy time. Warned to go up to the Pits tonight. A good number are changing over tonight. Received one letter only. Arrived at the Pits about nine and after a look at the gun turned in.The digout is immediately 

behind the gun. At 11Pm a shell landed five yards from dug out, filling it with dirt and smoke. Another came close, shortly afterwards, so we left and went to a flank. Came back 30 minutes after & turnedin for a while, but he shelled again, so we slept in trenches a couple of hundred yards away. Coming back at four AM, he landed a 5.9 ? afew yards in front of us. We fell on the ground so no one was hurt. Arrived at dug out and waited for daylight. He had the "wind " up us completely.
Entry.187: Had breakfast at 9AM, then tried to sleep. He put a few more shells over at intervals of 30 minutes or so. Five of our 'planes and the same number of Fritz's "boxed on", the latter getting the best of it. It is fine weather. Had a quiet night which was muchly appreciated
Entry.188: The Padre came around and had a talk to usabout news in general. Had a lecture in afternoon concerning Battery in open Warfare etc. Wrote a few letters. Received about eighteen Aussie letters, so was set for the night. Fritz put a few coal boxes over us (shrapnel) pieces came very close. We were sitting in dug out having tea when one piece came into the centre of our group cutting one chaps pocket and its contents. He put a good number of gas shells over at 4AM till 6 AM.
Entry.189: Arose early and had a clean up Then wrote letters and cleaned the dug out. On guard at night, was lucky getting first shift. The weather is good and Fritz quite idle.
Entry.190: Had a little sing song in dug out. A 'plane evidently was caught in some wind about 10,000 feet up, breaking his both wings off at body. He took some time to get down, being up at such a height. Whether he was a Fritz, French or British none could say. He would be dead ere reaching the groundThe wings took about ten minutes to come down. Fritzy is ranging today and is not far out. Just put a Gal Bose (Shrapnel Shell) over the Battery. Men went to their dug outs like rabbits to a burrow. We are pulling out in a few days time.
Entry.191: Nothing worth noting happened during the day. The usual amount of shells sent over to us by Fritz. E Sub doing shoot for the night.
Entry.192:
Up at 3AM and fired off shoot till 5.30AM. At 4 am Fritz put over numerous gas shells making working of gun awkward, having to put on Gas Respirator. Most of shells contained sneezing gas which is also a lachrymative making my eyes water for some time. He put a little Phosgene over also.

Had breakfast at the pits then came down to waggon lines. Had a swim and a talk to three old 31st Reviftsboys, being pleased to see them. The guns were pulled out about noon,the 27th Batteryrelieving us. They have just been out for a couple of weeks monouvres at Abbeville. Received a parcel from Home. contents soon disappearing. Splendid weather. Fritz put some large stuff on Railway & roads near by about 2PM
Entry.193: Rolled our overcoats and kits, (of course in regimental style) we are now out of action, hence the extra attention of windy officers, scarcely seen when in action. Moved off at 7.30AM. Our Battery led the Column so did not have many unnessary halts. passed through the outskirts of Amiens, which is very much destroyed by shell fire. The travelling was hot and roads dusty. The only village passed throughof any size was Piquegny. Halted along road for lunch and at 4PM pulled into open field for night. The both Brigades are close together. Not many old chaps who came over with the 31st Reinfts. The country around is very fertile & picturesque. France constantly has fine avenues of trees. Went for a walk after tea with Pink. Many chaps have been evacuated with effects of gas. Slept out in open.
Entry.194: Reveille at 5 AM. Pulled out onto road about 7.30 AM, passed through Airames; the largest town passed during route. Typical of the French villages. The French :Soldats: are in larage numbers about here. Had dinner about noon. The country passed through is well cultivated and very undulated. Small forests are numerous. Arrived at our camp which is in the village of Cocqueral eleven miles from Abberville. Our lines are on the crest of a hill from which a panoramic view of surrunding country can be obtained. The Somme River is close at hand. We are billeted in barns.
Entry.195:
Phyical Drill from 5.30 AM till 7.30 AM From 9AM till ! PM we had Battery manouvres in open field. Not too

many know much about the movements from officers- down. Had a half- holiday, so went down to the Y.M.C.A. and had a read. Watered the horses at 5PM. After tea Pink and self went for a walk to neighbouring vilage, three and a half kilometres, by name Pont Remy about eight times the size of the village we are billeted in. Has one main street and a few shops. The River Somme passes through the villge. A few Americans could be seen; they are mating up with the Australians O.K. As usual many Australians were "full". Met Jack Jacobs and a couple of other Liverpool chaps, so we strolled through the village together. The 11th Brigade is a good distance from our village . The weather is fine.
Entry.196: Watered the horses till Breakfast Had Battery manouvres again. The three Batteries were out together. Events passed off much better, than on previous day. In the afternoon a Tammy Sergeant gave a lecture on the Buffer and how it is worked. This is an air Buffer which takes place of the oil one. It is less expensive & more serviceable when firing at a long range. Did not go out at night.
Entry.197: Had a rehearsal of Divisional Parade about noon when General Burges who is in charge of 4th Division F.A inspected us. The movements went off successfully, two Brigades being present. Had a supper at night with Pink & a couple of other chaps. It was a pleasant change
Entry.198: Had a stroll around town in morning doing a picquet. Did not overwork ourselves. Had the afternoon off but did not go out
Entry.200: On guard all day. The Division was inspected by Generals Birdwood & Monash. Not feeling too well.
Entry.202: Went down to a Rest Hut. Have some kind of French Fever. About a hundred in Brigade are down with it. On Wednesday Divisional Races were held. I believe it was chiefly an Officiers show. Still have a temperature.
Entry.203:
Brigade Sports are being held today. The Doctor evacuated me today to a British Casualty Clearing Station.

at Longpre, about eight kilometres from Battery. The No of C.C.S. is 12. Had a good time here, good food and plenty of rest. The wards are full of Influenza. Got up after a few days here. Left on
Entry.204: for the line. Came as far as Pernois for the night, Billeting at a Rest Station.
Entry.205: Came back to our Divisional Wing Headquarters at Bertrancourt. Had dinner here. Achap from 39th Battery is also here so we went through this village. It is very slow and nothing to see. Came back and turned in.
Entry.206:
Went down to theGas School and issued with a respirator. In afternoon we fixed up a Tennis Court. The 5th Division Concert Party, "Kookaburras"

bynamed are showing in this village there They give a good show. A large number of Infantry came into the night, also a few Artillery.
Entry.207: Went down to Gas School again with the crowd and had a lecture on various gas. At night we went to the Y.M.C.A. Cinema Show which was very good.
Entry.208:
1918,

Moved off with the Infantry towards the line doing in all about twenty kilometres for the day. We were all footsore when the march was finished. Stopped at Rest Camp near Vaux. This village is dead.
Entry.209:
About six of us moved off about 5.30 AM so as to miss the party

as we could not walk too well, being very stiff. At 7AM we arrived at Amiens 8.6 kilos and immediately caught Motor Lorries to Querrie 12 kilos away. From here we made numerous inquiries as to location of our Brigade. At 10AM we arrived at Battery which is on outskirts of Daours. The Orderly Room have sent all letters of mine into Hospital so will have to wait an indefinite time for them. All my Kit is also lost so Im not too Happy. Pink managed to save six letters for me. Fritz 
He
 shelled about this vicinity at night.
Entry.210: Mess Orderly for the day, so assisted the cook. On guard at night. Pink is also on. E Sub Gun was knocked out by a direct hit. The Sub Section came down tonight. Aeroplanes are very active.
Entry.211: The Gun came down early this morning. A 4.2: H.E hitthe right wheel. The Buffer is blown about, shield & Dial Sight also smashed. The weather is fine. The waggon Lines are situated amongst tall trees, with a fine stream close at hand.
Entry.212: Cleaned the camp up and loaded the limbers with ammunition. Had half-holiday so played a game of cricket till 4 PM. Wrote a few letters.
Entry.213:
Did usual work or loaf in Waggon Park. The weather is too fine to work hard consequently little is done until an Officer appears & then all start "tootsweet".A stunt is coming

off in a few days time. The traffic on road is enormous. Limbers after Limbers file in and load up, at the dump opposite, motor wagons hurry past riggling through the congested traffic. Os Ferns came around to see me tonight. He looks well but much older. We had a great talk for about three hours. He is camped the other side of this village; where his Battalion is out resting prior to going in the line and over the top. Went up with the waggons at midnight, a gunner has to go on each limber in case a driver is wounded or killed to take his place or give assistance. Fritz has the position of Battery very well and puts them right onto them when he likes, as he has direct observation from a higher hill close by. On

leaving the main road onto the wheat field,. You have to travel about two kilos over flat country & owing to Fritz shelling it persistently the drivers have named it "Windy Flat" as it puts the "wind up" all. There are numerous shell holes on this track and the gunner gets a rough ride, behind some of the drivers, the springs on the limbers never seem to work. It is a case of hang on a hope the limber doesn't go over. The moonlight however has eliminated a good deal of the going into shell holes.
Entry.214:
Up as usual and watered horses. Cleaned up camp and made bomb proof shelters for horses. The day has been beautiful. Os Femscame around tonight and we had another

long talk. They have a platoon of "Yanks" in each company, as we are very much under strength in our infantry Battalions. Os said they are fine fellows, keen and fine physique. They should acquit themselves well. Fritz blew out our water-cart; killed both horses & wounded the driver in both arms. He put three "duds" in front of F Sub Gun. Poor left section is in for a bad time when the stunt opens out. The chap who was wounded on 21st April from this Battery had stiff luck, dying of his wounds received. He died in England.
Entry.215:
Did usual work in morning building Bomb proofs for horses. Did not overwork ourselves. Had a half holiday till 4 PM when

the horses had to be watered. Warned to go up to the gun as it came back today. This was cancelled at the eleventh hour instead I went on guard. The "Hop over" started at 3 AM when all Artillery commenced their deadly fire, a fire that takes nerve to face. The Infantry "jumped the Bags four minutes afterwards when the Barrage lifted a few yards.
Entry.216:
Fritz was surprised, the Infantry meeting raiding parties, and our chaps were in Fritz's line ere his Barrage opened out, thus the casualities were only half as many as suspected and all the objectives obtained in a couple of hours, with a couple of thousand Huns prisoners of war. The "Yanks" proved good fighters, and

many were too eager with the result that some were killed with our own shells. Three thousand yards was the greatestadvance although they could have gone on much further unmolested into a small village but orders are orders. The Huns who came to the cafe opposite our lines are a fine body of men as regards build and condition. Wounded Fritzs' were brought in with our own wounded. I had to go up to the pits with the water cart and a party of "Yanks" stopped us and said. "Whydo you waste gasoline on those _______?" pointing to an ambulance car with wounded Huns in. I told them Fritz generally gives our captured wounded good treatment. Our battery had no

casualities although the 38th had two detachments casualities. They expect business tonight when he counter-attacks. Had a hot bath today so feel fresh. The weather is still fine.
Entry.217:
Did usual work in morning, loaded the waggons with ammunition then Pink and self had a sleep for a couple of hours being tired, having had little sleep the previous night, owing to Fritz Bombing Planes picking out our waggon line surroundings as a fit place to drop somewhere near one hundred bombs over a couple of hours. Much to our surprisenot one bomb dropped in our camp area, although all around he put them. He dropped a good many flares. Went up to the pits at night to stay

Pink also came up.There are now only three gunners on gun,unloaded two waggons of ammunitions and carried shells to pit. Pretty hot work too climbing bank with four shells. He dropped a dud alongside gun at 11.30 PM. Fired sixty rounds off and at 3 AM another sixty, three rounds per minute. Turned in at 5 AM. A large House in Corbie near at Hand, caught fire and illuminated surrounding country up.
Entry.218:
Up at 9.30 AM for breakfast, then turned in till dinner at 2 PM. Had a clean up and wrote several letters till tea at 6 PM. He put over a little gas. We have a good dug out made by the engineers. Will hold four. On S.O.S guard from 11.30 PM till 1.45 AM. It was very quiet

The ammunition came up at 2 AM so helped unload and carry it to the pit. Had a shoot at 2.30 AM firing sixty ronds. Received about ten Aussie letters.
Entry.219:
Up for meals, could not sleep much during day. Wrote a couple of letters and had a read. A party came up from rear waggon lines to dig forward gun pits as we are moving up shortly. They are going to be in the reserve trenches. Had a sleep till midnight when we set the fuzes for the shoot. A raid was to be carried out on our left and we had to cover the flank. Fired one hundred and thirty odd rounds, three to the minute. It is hot dirty work. Cleaned the pit of empties & then unloaded waggons and carried ammunition to

the Pit. Had to be ready for an S.O.S.We evidently captured the few hundred yards in question as the stunt went off OK.Fritz did not counter attack.
Entry.220: Up at 2 PMand cleaned up. Wrote letters till 6 PM & had tea. It is very quiet here today. Had a shoot at 10 PM sixty rounds as Fritz was bringing up guns,and they thought he would attack. It was a general shoot on all the sector. Unloaded the ammunition then turned in. Fritz is holding this line very thinly. It is believed he is waiting for men slightly wounded to return & men who have contracted this Dogs' Disease which is so prevalent amongst troops at present.
Entry.221:
Rained a little today, but afternoon was dry. wrote letters till dusk.

On Guard from 1.45 AM till 4AM. Battery had to "stand to" for an hour ,as they thought Fritz was Hopping over. Did not have any shoot last night.
Entry.222: Weather somewhat dull & showers have fallen at intervals. Wrote letters in afternoon. Did sixty rounds at midnight. General shoot. Waited for ammunition at 1.30 AM then turned in
Entry.223: Weather is rather dull and had a little rain. Os Ferns sent a card saying he was wounded in the "Hop over" of 4th instant. Had a couple of small shoots at a couple of hours interval. Had to stand to from 3 AM till 4 AM.
Entry.224:
On guard from 11.30 PM till 1.45 AM

Had several shoots during the night. The planes of both sides were extremely busy, and the searchlights surrounding Amiens were kept going. They formed an unique sight with the numerous streams of light piercing the sky. It is very hard to pick a plane up at night.
Entry.225: Received photos taken in England last night. They are not too bad. Had letters from Maurice Hole a "Karoola " mate. Today has been uneventful. We are pulling out tomorrow I believe.
Entry.226:
Up at the usual time and in afternoon wrote a few letters, and had a read. After tea we have a rifle practice and the .303 bullets

used number manf, so do the holes in surrounding . Had usual shoot at night.
Entry.227: Up at 2 Pm when the third Division relieved us, taking over our gun and pit. We packed kit on a G. S waggon and came down to the waggon lines. Had a hot bath & played cricket at night.
Entry.228:
Getting up at 6.30 AM was very hard. Cleaned the Horse-lines then packed. Kit to go to relieve the 2nd Division. Saw a few 31st Reinftschaps at the lines, being in Battery that is relieving us. Left at 6 PM and after a long trip eventually arrived at the Pits. E Sub were lucky in not getting a Gunas it had gone to Ordinance for repairs. The positions

is not too bad. We are in front of Heilly on Morlancourt Sector.
Entry.229: Not much to do. The Battery fired a few rounds per gun at 11PM. Ammunition came up at 12 PM. Had to go over to Brigade to get the correcttime. Theyare in a large chateau. It is very old and the walls of ground are immense, being built for a seige in early days. It is the largest chateau I have seen. Had heavy rain for a while
Entry.230:
Had a read till dinner then wrote letters. The French seem to have defeated the Hun offensive in the south. Will Carswell came over to see me today, he is just a couple

of hundred yards away to our left. Was greatly pleaed to see him, made Home seem much closer. He is very thin and fed up with the war. Four years is quite enough for anyone. Had a talk for a few hours. Our gun is not yet up. He shelled the gully a little in morning.
Entry.231: Put the usual issue over in morning at 9 AM. They are all dropping about a hundred to our right. Pieces are numerous and dug outs "favourite". Not forgetting the old tin Hat. Did a little fatigue in the morning then read a book. In afternoon went over to see Will Carswell as they are pulling out at 6 PM tonight. Was pleased to meet him indeed. Ammunition came up at 10 PM when we carried a few rounds to our pit.
Entry.232:
Up at 6 AM having to go to Brigade with Intelligence Report. It is a three kilometre walk into Heilly where the Headquarters are situated. It was glorious walking amongst the wheat in such a lovely morning. The birds do not seem to mind the "La Guerre"carrying on. They chirp away to their hearts content. It is a pleasant sound to the ear; a peaceful sound after the continual cr-crash of all sizes of shells, and the report of our own. Had a bath in a bucket of water when I came back from Brigade H.Q. and then wrote a letter. The insects are a nuisance in this position, particularly by the mosquito & fly. Aeroplanes as usual are busy this morning. Had a read. Went to Brigade Headquarters in afternoon

carried up a little ammunition to the pit. Our gun did not turn up tonight so had a good sleep.

Sunday 21st July1918

Cleared the pit and helped on a dug out all day. Received a few Aussie letters dated up to
Entry.233: Our Gun came up at 11.30PM but having no Dial Sight could not put in action. The weather is again cloudy
Entry.234:
July1918

Cleaned the gun up and put it into action.The carriage is old but it has a new bore. Wrote a few letters. The sun was good oh. Carried ammunition up at dusk. I had a night off as only two gunners are required to work it, the shoots being small and hourly

The gun failed to run up after a couple of shoots,so had to put it out of action again.
Entry.235:
Had the gun to pieces. The springs are too large for new spring case. Fired a couple of rounds 106 fuze (sensitive) onto dug outs. About five minutes afterwards. Fritz retaliated and sent over a dozen to us. They landed about fifty yards away. The news in paper is good concerning the Marne-Aisne Front.

It has rained heavily most of today. Put the day in sleeping. Did the shooting tonight. Had five "shoots" which meant staying up all night as there was an hourly interval between firing.
Entry.236: Had a read and sleep to put the day in.On guard at night for an hour. Nothing occurred worth mentioning. Weather is still showery.
Entry.237: Carried up & close on a hundred rounds to pit. It is extremely hard work, having to carry them close on one hundred yards up hill. A few trips soon knocks you out. Had six shoots during night. Had a sixty round shoot at 10 AM when we covered the right flank of a Hofover on our left. Used mostly smoke. Still dull weather.
Entry.238:
Carried up ammunition; twelve teams came up, so we expect

a stunt shortly. Had a night off and was not sorry, for it rained most of the night
Entry.239: Rained most of the day making the ground very slushy & hard to keep your feet. Sixteen teams came up tonight, so we had a busy hour. The Right Section did all shoots to night so had another night off. Received a parcel from London containing things I had sent over for. A mate also received an Aussie parcel and I helped him to get away with some of the contents.
Entry.240:
Went down to B.H. Q. this morning with despatch, E sub being duty sub. He put 4.2 salvos onto our Battery, thanks to the Woodbines who drew the crabs yesterday when

they worked at dug outs & pits under Balloon observation. We are getting all the "overthrows" which makes the posseyuncomfortable. The Left Section had to do the shoots tonight, Had three shoots of fifteen Rounds Gura Fireeach, so had competition with F. Sub. They won by a round as we had to push the gun up everytime. The rangers came out for ' the stunt' at 11.40 PM so we had to set to and set the fuzes
Entry.241:
The Barrage opened out at 12.30 AM when all guns from Eighteen pounders to 9 inch spoke up. This lasted till 1.20 AM when we set to with the fuzes for next barrage which opened out at 1.35 AM. Our gun now being hot would not run up so three had to push it up

making already Hot work much more strenuous. Our troubles started now for the wall of the pit fell in, and the camouflage also. Through these matters , we managed to send over one aminute. Hun planes came and dropped two parachute flares over the Battery. We soon Hugged the walls of pit waiting for bombs. The flares lasted about five minutes ( to us tit seemed like five hours). No bombs or machine gun bullets came so we set about the work again, although the thought of Fritz above never left our minds. He put over Gas shells at 4 AM, but we did not get much of it. Put a dozen shells over on our S.O.S.at 5 AM then "stood down". The operation was a complete success

gaining 800 yards on 4000 yard front with slight casualties. Had a sleep, then a relief came up for each sub so came down to Waggon Lines about seven miles back near Freisancourt.
Entry.242: Washed the Waggons down at creek in the morning then oiled them inafternoon. Had a swim down at creek, and it was a luxury indeed to me having had no bath for so long. Played the Tommies cricket in evening, who beat us by seven wickets. We scored 25 in first,108 in second innings, while they scored 80 in first.
Entry.243:
Put Hay sacks on Limbers in readiness to move out of here. The fourth Div Infantry have gone in at

Hangard south of Villiers-Brettoneaux just to the right of our position before going in at Morlancourt Sector. Have half holiday so wrote a few letters Home. It is fairly hot tonight. Fritz came over at 12.30AM and gave this locality more than its share. He came over in three relays, so we had little sleep that night. Of course we had the "Wind Up" completely. The troops hate the bombs; to hear the Burr-r of the machine,and the thought of bombs comiing onto you. He dropped several within one hundred yards of us.
Entry.244:
Put the morning in loafing. In afternoon washed the Gun Limber then disappeared. Fritz' planes came over at 3PM and set on fire four of our Balloons. The occupants of them came down "tootsweet" landing safely

in trees. Had a game of cricket at night. We were easily defeated by the 54th AFA Battery. The Tommy Batteries are around ready to take over from us.
Entry.245: Raining fairly heavy, so little work was done. Read most of morning. In afternoon wrote letters. The guns came down tonight. Was on guard from 4AM till 7AM.
Entry.246:
The country is looking very well although the fields are gradually losing their colour and puts one more in mind of Australia with the Brownish grass. Packed the limbers and moved out at 2PM proceeding to Daows from where we had recently left. Pulled into a chateau grounds, made horse lines then put the covers up

Had a good sleep. Ammunition went up, leaving it at a dump near Hamel. The guns are going into action close up to the front line, just for the stunt, so we expect a busy time. There are no objectives.
Entry.247: Up at 6 AM and turned into stables. Had an easy day. Went for bath in afternoon. The chateau grounds are lovely with fine trees and stream running through. There is a tennis court but is minus Rackets etc. Wrote letters at night.
Entry.248:
Did work around camp, tied and packed loose bolts on the limbers so that Fritz will not hear them going up to the position. Packed our kit up ready to go up with the guns. Our gun came back. It is not

much good. Wet weather has set in making things very miserable especially just before a stunt. The whole gun detachment was changed around at the eleventh hour. Military organisation again. Was glad that I never had to go up now as it was a wretched night. The range of gun for this stunt is 1500 yards. We are in front of Hambel near Corbie. Hundreds of tanks have gone up and they seem to have the bestfighting material in the way of men, for the Canadians, Scotch, Americans & Aussies are in large numbers. The whole five divisions are down for it.
Entry.249:
Did stables and had a rest generally. Put a bridge on E sub Firing Battery waggon to be put

over Fritz's trench to enable the guns to advance over onto next position, which will be between the first and second Fritz lines. Rained fairly heavy during day. Went down to test the canteen stores, was not very successful. The stunt is coming off on the eigth. So rumour goes. F sub gun went up tonight.
Entry.250: It is a fine morning. Sunshine brings with it a differerent aspect on things, making me cheerful. Packed up the waggons and proceeded at 8 PM to the outskirts of the village of Hamlet going through the much battered villages of Aubigny & Fouilloy. Camped in a wheatfield till 4 AM. Did not sleep much owing to the cold.
Entry.251:
I am a runner in this stunt mounted on a bicycle. My first job was to proceed with Gun Limbers and Firing Battery Waggons up to the gun position some distance up. Travelling was most unpleasant owing to a dense fog. The Barrage opened up at 4.20 AM when all guns let loose their various sizes and kinds of projectiles. The "Heavies" close by smothered the noise of the Field guns. Hell on earth let loose, but what of where the shells were falling. After two hours of this tornado our guns moved up at the gallop to take positions in Fritz recent country. As the guns fired the Infantry boys cheered for we were well up near Fritz & I think it surprised them to think we were up so soon. I went back

to the First Line Waggons which then came on through the village of Vaire-Corbie remaining till the order to move up still further. The fog was still very heavy, which although it assisted the tanks, Artillery could not get good observation. Our Brigade did a remarkable feat in getting into action some time before the Imperial Royal Horse Artillery who are specially trained for this open warfare, having suitable horses for light & quick work. At this position Fritz put over a few 5.9 making things uncomfortable. E sub gun went out of action here but was fixed up in time to join the Battery at another position further on about 8 kilometres from the old line. In the meantime the rear waggon lines came up taking its position in the old no man'sland.

Fritz had had no trenches; just advance posts and numerous machine gun positions. Our Infantry met with little opposition here. A number of Hun dead were to be seen. We had a look round their posy. Most had good dugouts. The dead had ghastly wounds, some without legs and many with half their heads blown away. This is my first experience of actual warfare, and these fresh sights will not be easily forgotten. The guns were now using open sights at 500 yards range on machine gun positions which were causing the Infantry a good deal of trouble. We blew the guns away but his Artillery on a height on the left flank poured enfiladefire onto our guns, causing much damage to the Brigade. We lost four killed

and several wounded in our Battery the other Batteries fared much worse & 110th had tenkilled and the 38th over twenty. We pulled back from this position. Machine gun bullets came onto the position also, wounding a few men. Owing to the Tommies meeting with great opposition on our left flank near Chippilly we had to stop 1500 yards below our objective. The waggons were kept busy all day taking up ammunition to the guns. In the afternoon we suffered casualities among the drivers, several being wounded. Many horses were killed and several wounded. We captured eight Fritz's horses which were utilised in the teams. Four of these were killed later. Managed to get a few souvenirs. The prisoners are numerous and all appear to

to be in good condition. Some are young. All seem pleased at being captured; perhaps the mere fact that they have come out with a whole skin is sufficient to make them that way. Our Light Horse did excellent work in advance, capturing a Brigade Headquarters and a large gun on railway. At night the Hun planes came over doing their evil work. They put the "Wind" up the troops more than anything else. Had a good sleep at night beiing very tired.
Entry.252:
The Infantry had small local stunts but could not advance owing to left flank not advancing sufficient. Went to D. A. C. for a G.S. Waggon to go up to the Pits for the four chaps who were killed. They were burried

at Vaire - Corbie with the rest of the Brigade. It being necessary that the left flank should advance,at 5.30 PM the English and American troops moved forward to the attack supported by tanks and a very heavy Artillery fire which we observed from a hill opposite. It was a great spectacle watching the Barrage. The fighting was very determined, the Huns having ideal defensive ground. The Height was soon taken, the enemy going towards Bray. Morlancourt fell to us after fierce hand-to-hand fighting. The Tommies a London Regiment lost Heavily on the Height overlooking Chippilly. They fought bravely unlike some English Regiments, although our Government has no room to speak about Germany sending

eighteen year old boys in the line. A number of guns were captured in this stunt.
Entry.253:
Things were very quiet this morning a small stunt took place at 10AM. At night I went up with F.B.Waggons to the guns, but when half way up met them coming away, as they had to take up positions on the left flank. Passed through the villages of Cerisy-Gailly and Chippilly, both being almost levelled to the ground. Ours and his Artillery had done their work. The streets were covered with debris from the buildings: dead horses and shell holes added to the congestion. Gas was noticeable in the village. Pulled alongside steep hill ( taken previous night) for awhile, then guns went into action on crest of hill. He put a

few over while we were waiting. Went back for another load bringing it up to the guns. We then returned to forward waggon lines near the guns Hun planes were again busy, and made us uncomfortable by dropping flares and sweeping machine guns around the roads. When watering horses one dropped two aerial torpedoes and small bombs close by. We thought our day had come.
Entry.254:
Up at 4AM and went up to the guns; thinking they were advancing the village had much gas in it. Stood by till noon then came down to Gun teams and unhooked. While waiting we went for souvenirs, but did not get much. The wood has many English dead in it, but few Fritz's. The former put up a brave fight for the

Hell. The lads are very young, and it brings home to one the horror of war; men, fit one minute and the next lying dead on the Battle field. It is the Home folk who suffer. Many 4.2 guns are here intact, and are being worked by specially trained men. These are the Batteries that caused us much damage through enfilade fire. The guns are excellent pieces of invention. Their range is over 10,000. Went up to the gun relieving. Fired a few rounds at intervals during the night. He put a few bombs over near by.
Entry.255:
After dinner we had to build gunpit up with sandbags. Worked till tea then told to be ready to move out at anytime. Put a Barrage over at 1.30 AM when the Infantry

went over after some ground. It was a success. Pulled out at 3AM returning to the Rear Waggon lines
Entry.256:
Had a sleep till 10AM then prepared to move out. Moved at 2PM proceeding via Lamotte and Guillancourt to Harbonnieres where we stayed for tea. The rear waggon lines are staying here. As no orders have been received to move out we pulled the waggons alongside a bank in case of Bombs. Dug in a bit of a drain & turned in. The Hun planes came over in numbers but did not drop any bombs near. Our searchlights make a fine sight sweeping the sky withtheir bright streams They got onto one plane but did not bring it down. Pulled out

at 1AM, the guns and Firing Battery Waggons proceeding to the new position about 2000 yards in rear of the line. It was a long trip over the country,and to add to our being tired Fritz was strafing a good deal. Finally arrived at our position and unloaded the waggons, put the camouflage over the gun and looked for a dug out. After much trouble found one and turned in. He put over a barrage nearby but it did not trouble us much being too tired.
Entry.257:
Up at noon having breakfast then had a read. We have a good dugout, fairly large, with writing table and beds in it. Fritz lives well when he is at home. He shells this place a

a good deal. Formerly it was used by him as a Rear Waggon lines as stables have been erected and used. The surrounding country is very level with touches of bushes here and there. It is extremely hot today. Up to the present we have captured much material. Over a million bombs are in the village on left and we passed en route to position dumps etc. A couple of large guns could be seen on the road. Fritz used the railway to some extent. There is to be a large hop over here in a few days or they expect him to come over. We are a silent Battery being so close to front line, on our left is Bayonvillers and in front his Lihons. Lamotte is almost levelled to the ground being in a hopeless

ruin. There is not a roof on a house. The church has one part of wall standing. Dug pit at night
Entry.258: We were very tired from previous night's work. Digginga gun pit is hard work, and with the ever buzz of Hun's planes over head one does not feel extra pleased with himself. Fritz put over a very heavy Barrage at 3.30AM till 5AM keeping us awake sometime. The sentry failed to wake us up when gas came over, with the result all received a good deal of it, ere we could get our masks on. At night fixed up the pit and camouflage working till midnight. Our guns are very quiet and do not retaliate. The weather is very warm and dry.
Entry.259:
He Put over some Barrage this morning, especially on the wood to our left, for in it is a large ordnance dump etc; twelve Aussies have been killed trying to get some sugar and other luxuries. There is 2000 ton of sugar, much Jam flour etc etc. Down on our right the French are busy for the rumble of both Barrages (His and ours) can be heard. The ground seems to shake or rather tremble under you. In the afternoon our Heavies woke up, and it was indeed a cheerful noise after such subdued silence. Since that Fritz has not sent so many over. To the righrt of Rozieres which is directly behind us, you can see ours and his shells bursting, the country being so flat They are only 2000 yards away &

have direct observation on our position, which makes it very unhealthy. It is rumoured the French have advanced so he may withdraw from here. We are on Sauterie Plateau the Infantry being in the old Somme trenches. A chap was saying that our Infantry are only a few yards away from Fritz and bomb throwing goes on to some extent. Even the dug outs are petitioned off by sand bags, both sides using it. (that is a large dug out). 

Did alittle to put in the way of sand baggingit. On guard from 2 AM till 3.30 AM. Fritz is fairly quiet. Shelled the wood alittle. Put three shells over near Battery at about 3AM two going well over but the third went right into a sub dug out, blowing one lad to pieces, and

burying the others. I was standing five yards away doing guard, went down on prone and was covered with dirt. I immediatly went for assistance and we soon had them dug out. None were hit. It is marvellous the escapes you have.
Entry.260: Things are very quiet in this front this morning. Weather is alittle dul. Dug some ammunition up in pit. Had a quiet day. Fritz not worrying us much. Had a good sleep till 4AM when we throught Fritz was hopping the bags. It was on our left.
Entry.261: Wrote several letters today. It has been windy & cold. Nothing of importance has occurred today. Fritz brought one of our balloons down about 4pm. Put more sandbags up on the sides of the pit.
Entry.262: Did little allday except write a few letters and have a read. At 7PM we had an S.O.S. when we let them go at the toot. It lasted ten minutes only. Machine gun bullets went over our head with a Gipping noise. As the line is close on 2000 yards away, the flatness of country can easly be realised when bullets will come that far. We learnt afterwards that Fritz had made a raid also our Infantry. The Canadians are giving him a lot of worry. The rest of night was quiet.
Entry.263: Did little work in morning. Wrote a few letters in afternoon. On guard for a couple of hours. Fritz was pretty quiet. A dense fog was on similar to morniing of stunt.
Entry.264: Extremely hot during the day, at night we had to dig fresh pits which meant solid hard work till early hours of morning. Our army is certainly a Key stone with mug officers running it. They say keep under cover during day, yet they have an inspection under observation of Fritz's Balloon to see that you have had a shave. It is full moon tonight. Received much Australian mail some of June & May dates. They were exceedingly welcomed.
Entry.265:
Fritz put a few salvos over this morning getting the cook. Stiff luck getting such an important man. It is very hot with little breeze so all feel more or less tired.

carried ammunition from old pit to new. Finished at 11PM and turned in till 4AM.
Entry.266: Had a stunt at 4.50M when the "Aussies" on our left flank hopped over. The result I have not heard yet. He put a little H.E & shrap over us to no effect. Slept most of the day. One from each detachment went down in pill box. We are pulling out today I believe. Weather is rather dully.
Entry.267:
Had a good sleep last night. Fritz is putting a few shrapnel shells over us. Had a read. The waggons come up empty and loaded up at the pits, the last getting away about 11PM. Came

down to waggon lines through Rosieres. The French Infantry & Artillery are taking over from us.
Entry.268: Had a rest till noon. At 2PM we moved out waiting at Giullancourt for the rest of the Brigade. We came to the outskirts of Corbie about 5PM passing through Lamont, Fouilloy etc. Corbie is a very large twon and although greatly damaged is crowded with Aussies of all the Divvies, evidently returning from the Base. In the square is to be seen two large Heavy Guns (about 8 inch) captured by the Australian Infantry on the 8th. Camped in field. Rained most of night although unpleasant it meant no bombing planes of Fritz's visiting us.
Entry.269: On the road at 8AM coming to the outskirts of Amiens, to a village of Camon about the usual size of a French village. We are camped about Kilos out of village in a small bush or forest. Horse\lines are already made so that means less work for us. Made a Humpy so we are set.
Entry.270:
Did usual work around the camp. In afternoon went in search of Canteens. Was not too successful. From our camp you can see the most of Amiens. The fields look O.K. with the Harvesting soon on and hay stacks in the making. Had an excellent sleep having extra blankets. They were very welcomed.

Wenesday
Entry.271: With five other chaps I went down to the village of Camon & cleaned out several Houses which are to be used by our troops as billets. It was a good easy job; we made it so. In afternoon obtained canteen stores for mess. Heavy gun fire can just be heard down here so guess Fritz is getting plenty of iron rations. It has rained alittle during day. Received a few letters from Home.
Entry.272: On fatigues all day cleaning up the camp, at night five of us went to see the
Entry.273:
Division Concert Party "Smart Sets" by name. They were very good and we put in an enjoyable evening. Saw Jim Brooks but did not speak to him.

Cleaned up the camp again. Quite an easy job the way we do it? Did my washing at night, a pleasant job, I don't think. The weather is perfect and rain has kept off so far. Wrote a few letters.
Entry.274: Did usual fatigues during day and at night wrote letters. The weather is dull.
Entry.275:
The gunners had an early breakfast and started out to the Hot Baths at 7.30 am. Had a brisk walk of a couple of kilos. The bath & clean clothes went well, we all felt like new men after it. In the afternoon another chap & self walked over to Longeau to where the Fritz guns

are parked. It was a fine sight never to be forgotten. About two hundred guns in all, calibres ranging from 3 inch to 11 inch, also naval guns. The "Minniewerfers"? although they have an immense bore are small guns used in "supports", the work of these is mainly on machine gun positions. The next in size is the well known "Pip-squeak" a shell of about nine poundwith a sharp head. The Infantry see more of these than other units. Wizz-Bang" a shell of 3 inch calibre is sent from a gun much like our own 18 pounder it being one of His field guns. The name is derived from the noise the shell makes whilst in the air, followed by the explosion. It is a "toot sweeter" that is comes very quickly. The next gun is the field gun 4.2 inch, most commonly

order parade, a kind of rehearsal prior to the parade tomorrow. In the afternoon went as an escort with a chap to the "clink" at Daours but found Fritz's in it, so returned to Battery after a good ride across the fields. It was a nice time for a spin. It is very cold at night.
Entry.276: Had an Inspection of Division by Major-General Sinclair McClagan who commands rthe
Entry.277: Divie. He is an old guy, went passed in Column of Route, coming back through outskirts of Amiens. At night I went down into Camon & bought some canteen stores. The French work fairly late in the fields and have most of hay gathered in.
Entry.278: Had gun drill all the morning. It is stale work. There was a sports meeting but I did not go being too tired. It was not much good. Turned in early.
Entry.279: Cleaned the camp up during the day and at night five of us went down to see the change of programme of the Smart Sets. It was splendid and we put in a good night. The programme was much better than on opening night.
Entry.280:
Packed up the gun gear ready to put on the limbers as there is a strong rumour of us moving up the line. At night Pink, Honey & self went to a Froggy joint

for supper. The eggs went well.
Entry.281:
Received a rude awakening at 4 AM when the "Reveille" went. For the first half of it, I thought it was a part of a dream but soon I know the "Dinkum Oil'.
