Packed the waggons with the gun equipment and our Kits then had breakfast. Moved out at 9AM proceeding via Daours, Corbie up to Mericourt near Bray. Pulled into a Gully, which had numerous dugouts of the first order built by Fritz. As we pulled in who should be waiting for me but Bob Forsyth. He is attached to Corps Headquarters, billeted in the

going on Blighty Leave next week; he looks well although he has not grown at all, or altered. Have a decent bed. It is a shed with about fifty beds in it (wire netting) & table to eat at. Leading off from this is a large deep dugout. Shows Fritz thinks of his men more than our "Keystone Army". As long as you have a Bandolier on & chin strip down, you are O.K. Had a good sleep being tired after route march.
Entry.282:
Reveille at 6AM when horses were watered. It is over three kilos to the river so took a good while. After breakfast cleaned stables. Jack McKenzie on old mate of mine who came over with the 31st Reinforcements came over to see Pink & myself. He

is now in the Motor Transport Company, having left the 41st Battery the work being to strenuous for him; he being too old for the rough living & exposure to climatical conditions. We were glad that he got a comfortable position. He is a fine chap; had dinner with us then went back to his unit to get leave for the afternoon. He came back but we were busy packing the limbers "per drill book" as one of our Brainy Officer's said also. Owing to the new warfare Doug Haig said we must keep to the book as far as possible". Thus equipment must go on in the exact way & in many cases, useful articles had to be "dumped". Men must not put their little bit of bread or rations neatly on the footboard of limbers.

it must be carried where it cannot be seen. Thus our few little articles of food are packed in a small mess tin, the rest has to be "dumped" It is hard on us & things like this eat into our mind, making the feeling between 
men
 & officers far distant & bitter. I counted as we moved out in the column the number of "pill boxes" ued for officers & Sgts kits. There were no less than four. These conained messing gear & rations & Kits. Five drivers were employed & about eight horses. How many Batmen, Grooms & Cooks - well :- John Bull's next edition may be able to throw light on the actual number. Bob Forsyth came down to see me today again, the Corps having not moved as expected. We went over to see the 15 inch

Fritz Naval Gun captured by the 3rd Battalion 1st Division A.I.F. It is the largest gun captured since the war began. Its immense size is hardly creditable, & as you look at the fittings & bed, the work that has been put into it. you are bewildered. There is so much to see at once that you pause to think which end you will start at. The Bore, like a small gun, has many riflings & the piece is over fifty feet long, has the inner tube then another layer 6 inches thick over that, again another & yet another so the thickness of piece is easily two feet to two feet six inches. The bed is of solid concrete & iron supports, the traverse of gun is about 100 degrees. It stands from bottom

to top, a distance or rather height of about thirty to forty feet, having a huge steel platform around the Breech & in front. The shells are run up from a dug out to the Breech by a light Railway. They have built huge dugouts for the ammunition & shell cases. The gun is worked by electricity. Three lines run into the position which is in a small forest or wood. The gun has been blown up by the Firtz. They did the job properly. The piece is blown off near the breech, the latter is hard to find, being in many pieces. The bed is also in ruin. We came back to Corps Headquarters to see if I could find Alex Casserley who is now attached to the Corps. I had seen the 3rd Squadron on my way

to the gun, so made inquiries about him. Had no luck at the Headquarters, he is not there. Suppose he went to London. Met Dob Cairns also. Gave Bobsome souveniers to take to London for me to send Home.
Entry.283:
Moved off at 8AM coming up nearer the line, passed through the old 1916 line. The country is very desolate, burrowed out with trenches and dugouts which are all 4.2 evidently winter quarters for the troops. The trees are just sprouting again although they are knocked about. It is partly this that makes the country look so barren with the bare tree stamps sticking up on the field. Pulled into a paddock near Herbecourt six miles from Peronne. The country



is full of old shell holes, now covered with grass. In the afternoon we had to wash the waggons while drivers cleaned harness. This helps to win the war? Built a humpy & turned in. Rained heavily at night, our canvass letting a good deal in thus an interruped rest.
Entry.284:
Cleaned horse lines. It is very wet and rain seems to have set in for some time. Will Casswell who is now on some wireless stunt with his Brigade happened to be near as we came along the road so I again had a yarn to him. They are being relieved by us. He looks well. Did little today owing to the rain. Was on guard at night over a prisoner; the night proved rather cool for that kind

of a job. Received several Aussie letters which greatly revives one going or getting "fed up".
Entry.285:
Teams hooked in at 8AMN, Battery pulling out at 9AM. Came through barren country, ground that has been fought in time and again; the villages are villages no more, shells from both sides leave little standing, and one would pass along the road not seeing the village or knowing that one ever existed there, but for the signboard denoting name of village. The dugouts are numerous and each has a fireplace in it, evidently they were habitated during the winter of 1916-17. We travelled quickly in fact too much so for those who had to walk. The roads were muddy & weather

very unsettled. Fritz blew up many bridges & had roads mined near Peronne; this place now historical through fierce engagements of previous years is a Heap of Ruins. We left it on our left, proceeding in the direction of St. Quentin. Arrived at Moraucourt and relieved the 51st Battery 5th Division. Met several chaps whom I knew at Liveerpool. Capt Prior who was at Liverpool also when we were there is Adjutant of this Battery. E. Sub having no gun remained behind. The guns went into action about 4000 yards up, in a wood. Their S.O.S. range is 6800 yards. The Infantry have not come in contat with Fritz yet. Made a dugout. Rained fairly heavy all night.
Entry.286:
"Revielle" did not sound till 8AM owing



to most of the men being out till late. Did several odd jobs about the camp, and made our dugout rainproof. However immediately after tea we had to move up as our guns have gone up 4000 yards. We arrived at the old position where the guns were & made a waggon line. Put up horse lines in semi-darkness also our dugouts. The rain added more to our troubles. Turned in at 11PM very tired. The teams came back about midnight.
Entry.287: Still raining; the "Heads" did not know the watering points so after much delay they "fed up" without watering. Moved our dugout down to a better position. Loaded up the waggons with ammunition from the old position. Received letters at night from Aussie
Entry.288: Cleaned up the camp all the morning then had a read in the afternoon and wrote letters. It is still showery and rain seems to have set in. Cleared up at night however, so Fritz paid us a visit. Dropped some on neighbouring hill, close enough for all of us. Our searchlights got into two of them & they were brought down by one of the Artis' & the other by a plane.
Entry.289:
Received a parcel from Home, also several letters. The contents of former were soon devoured, especially the sweets. On guard during the day & then at night went up to pits with ammunition, taking it onto forward position about 2000 yards from line. Came back to present gun position

& reloaded taking it up to the forward position. It was a lovely moonlight night & Fritz was over, although not in large numbers. He dropped a few around, none coming near us.
Entry.290: Watered horses & helped to clean harness. Fritz put a few shells along the road we go along to water, & made us go at the "toot". It is extremely hot today. Teams went up with ammunition again tonight. Received a little mail. Saw Joe Cooper he is in the Mobile .
Entry.291:
Looked after a couple of horses during the day. Joe Cooper came around to my dugout & had a yarn. He has not changed much, showed each other's treasures which consist of photos only. Just finished

seeing them all when Fritz came over with Bombs. Lights out at the "toot" & on the prone. He put them near enough.
Entry.292:
"Reveille" went at 4AM when horses were watered and harnessed up to proceed up to gun positions. Left at 8AM & by 9AM wewere at thepits. The Barrage opened at 4.25AM but on our sector was very feeble. The infantry had little opposition for the first 3000 yards. Fritz did not send much back until early in afternoon, when he got near the new position of the Battery. Blew a team up. The gas proved a nuisance making many sick. I went up to the position & filled the limbers, & cleanrd the ammunition. We were then finishd for the day.

so I was really a civilian in this stunt. Stayed at the dump for the night; all teams stayed there. He came over in large numbers with 'planes & seemed to like our position. He kept our heads sown for some time. The rain came on again so that prevented further visits.
Entry.293: Up at 7AM harnessed up & came down to near waggon lines having Breakfast. The weather is still unsettled. Reiceived another issue of gifts from Australian Comforts Fund. Planes visited us at night.
Entry.294: Did usual fatigues during the day and at night went on guard. It is still dull weather. Received mail from Home. It is getting cold at night.
Entry.295: Did usual work at waggon lines, watered horses etc. & cleaned the limbers. The guns came out tonight. It is raining very heavy. Received several letters and answered a few.
Entry.296: The 1914 men left for Aussie today. From this Battery sixteen went, a good record. They were all in high spirits as can easily be imagined. They go via Paris & Italy, so will have a good trip. Received a parcel from home, with balaclava, cap etc. in it. It is a welcome gift.
Entry.297:
We are going into action again in a couple of days. Alex Ingram came around to see me. He has not altered much, looks well. Had a long chat about Home. He is in 106 How Bty with Joe Cooper.

played 17th Battery Rugby butthey won 13 to nil. At night cricket was played. The evenings are drawing in. A Hun 'plane had a go at one of the Balloons, but the "Auties" put up a good barrage & he came a "gutzer".
Entry.298:
Did the usual work. Am going up to the pits tonight. Pulled at at 6.30 pm. Saw Joe Cooper. We came to the left of old position by about ten kilos. Pulled up at waggon lines awaiting orders. After a stay of an hour or so the guns & waggons went forward passing through Roisela fairly large village much destroyed by shell fire. The officer lost us when in this village. We turned to come back, when a Fritz plane seeing us on he white road dropped

several Bombs, causing us to hurry and put the "wind" up us to the highest extent. The teams galloped through the village, but when at the end of the village, he dropped more, they fell on either side of the road & we thought the whole issue of us were finished. Bombs - cut them right out in next war please - Finally arrived at our position, or near it. There was a little delay owing to Fritz shelling the position. Pulled into action & commenced digging pits. Finished digging at 5AM & slept in open tench till 7AM when I woke up with cold feet & a drizzling rain which slightly wet my posssessions. There are Tommies in trenches resting - mere boys of eighteen.
Entry.299: Fixed the camouflage on gun & made ammunition racks, stacked the ammo in pit. He has shelled the place all day. In front on either side & behind, so we do not feel too much at home. There are no dugouts just have a trench cover up & dug in two feet. Had a look at a British Bomber that came down a couple of nights ago. Fritz shells it a good deal. Ammunication came up at night two loads per gun. Turned in but Fritz kept us awake with his continual shelling. A piece came through the dugout hitting me on the arm, luckily it was spent. Bruised the arm somewhat. It was a piece of the base of a shell about three inch square. He put gas over in morning. The Yanks are now up here.
Entry.300: Up at 9am for breakfast. Had a clean up, a very welcomed piece of work too. It is cloudy & rain is not far off. He is still shelling. Two loads of ammunition came up per gun. The Tommies in trenches left this afternoon, so we took a dugout in trench, which is much safer posey. He shells this far too persistently for my liking.
Entry.301:
Up at 5am as there is a stunt on at 5.30; the Yanks are hopping over after a few hundred yards prior to the big kick off in a few days. Advanced about 1500 yards but at 9am we had an S.O.S. Fritz put the Yanks back 500 yards. I believe the latter fought well.

but lack experience in consolidating their gains when they win. At noon Fritz got onto our battery getting a direct hit on C sub gun killing two & wounding three men. He has several balloons up quite close & could not help seeing us. There are so many batteries in small area & much movement on position. Ammunition came up a little earlier. Had shoots at frequent intervals during night. A couple of springs broke in our buffer but it was soon fixed up. He put gas over a night, getting a few men. One shell landed at door of dugout, putting the "wind" up us a good deal.
Entry.302:
Fairly cool today. He still puts the shells over. At 9pm we

moved up into new position prior to the stunt. Our leader lost us on the way up, but eventually we arrived at position about 11pm when the gun was put into action alongside the road & near a village by nearLempire. Have a Yank engineer attached to each gun to assist. Had a few winks in a trench close by till 5.30 pm. The barrage opened up at 6am & fairly heavy at that.
Entry.303:
The barrage went O.K. finish up at 9.30am, our range being 7300 yards having to dig trail in. He put a few 5.9 over during stunt. Had a sleep till about two. Did odd jobs, uncliping ammunition etc. Fired about 500 rounds in barrage. At about 4pm he opened up on our battery with 5.9 instantaneous bursts, putting all shells within

a yards square. Obtained direct hit on F sub gun & put several around it, also put two at the trail of our gun, but did not put it out of action. We huddle together in a small narrow trench, but even then he dropped them on either side of it. We had the "wind" up completely; personally it was the heaviest fire I have been under. Between the shots we managed to get away to a flank & it was a great relief too. No wonder the Hun prironers look so shell shocked coming back. It is a pity to see them in such a state. Found a dugout near a gun so the left section slept in there for the night. I was on guard from 12.30am to 2.30 am. The Yanks fought alright, but are inexperienced & did not mop
p
 up properly consequently when they advanced Fritz came out from behind with machine guns.

& did some serious work. At night none knew where the line was. Our S.O.S. came down some 400 yards. The 3rd &
Entry.304: Aussie Divisions came up & did good work in mopping up and finally made the flanks meet.
Entry.305: He has not shelled much this morning. Had a clean up & give guna little oiling. F sub gun went away today so we have now only four guns in action. Had a small shoot at 6pm. Salvaged an American Officers' Mess, so we had a few dainties for tea. Actually put sugar in our coffee ourselves, like old times alright. Had a quiet night. He put a few 5.9s over one falling at the entrance of our door, Plenty of gas in it too. It rained fairly heavy during night & was on the cold side.
Entry.306: It is a fine morning. Had a good clean up with hot water, so feel jake. He has not put many over today. It is raining a little.
Entry.307:
Up at 4am and moved out of position proceeding to our right to a village recently captured by name Bellicourt which is well over Hindenburg line. The subterranean canal is on our left rear. This is what held the adance up for a while, owing to large number of Fritzs' coming out at various parts & times. It was cleared however & the Infantry went forward towards St. Quentin. We dig our guns in under shell fire, but Fritz put the exact range on, so we left all & ran to a flank till he stopped. We are camped in a

Pill Box so it is fairly safe from 4.2 shells. One chap was wounded. We are getting fed up with this persistent shelling of position. The Major sent us all down to waggon lines, just leaving aguard there, as we are not responsible for an S.O.S. in this sector. It is some 5 kilometres to the W. lines and they are in a wretched position in a chalk pit.
Entry.308: Pulled out of this waggon lines & came over onto a hill some two kilos. It is now five kilos to water. Rather a long way? Slept out in a trench for the night. Rather cold. A few bombers came over.
Entry.309: It is very dull today. Am on no duty owing to being a little sick wrote letters. The gunners went up to the guns which moved three kilos
Entry.310:
The waggon lines moved up on the left of Bellicourt, near the canal which forms a strong point in the Hindenburg line. There are thousands of horses in the vicinity, all having to water from one place. Guess the congestion & delay. The banks of canal are very precipitous & dangerous in wet weather. Numerous Hun dugouts are built into the bank, some have been burnt out by Fritz. A number of his dead are along these places. It is excelent ground to defend in this area. Camped on top of a hill in trenches. Have sunken road as horse lines. In front is a small village, it has not been knocked about much. A few civilians were found in these

places. Land too had been cultivated up to recently. He came with usual amount of bombs at night.
Entry.311: It is extremely cold & wet. Did work in horse lines & managed to write a few lines home. Received a few letters from England.
Entry.312: The guns moved up a few yards today to a better position. He is not giving them too good a time up there. Very cold and wet. The weather seems to have broken, so we can expect a bad time ahead.
Entry.313:
Reveille went a little earlier, owing to teams having to go up to pits, there being a stunt on. Cavalry have been going up all morning. Hope they can operate & get him.

 farm

on the run. It is very cold outside & one hugs what fire he can get near. Received a letter from Ireland today. The clock went back an hour.
Entry.314: The teams went up again, as the guns had to go forward. Fritz is evidently on the run. The waggon lines moved up at 5pm about 8 kilos to a village by name Brancourt, which was in the hands of Fritz the morning before. Arrived at the place in the dark per usual. Luckily it did not rain & Fritz's bombing machines were not busy in our locality. Had tea & "turned in".
Entry.315:
Watered the horses & then salvaged a number of vegetables for the cook. Put one in mind of a harvest

Festival the variety that was collected. Fritz shelled us with 5.9 at various times during the day, getting three horses. A number of Yanks are along the bank waiting to move up the line. The guns went forward again about 6000 yards, Fritz having retired some distance. The waggon lines moved up past the old gun position going through ideal country not touched by war. It is a change to see fillages not knocked about by shells & the fields without a shell hole in them. Many French people are in these villages, having lived here under the Germans. The men have either been killed or sent back to Germany. Put up a humpy and retired for the night. The front line is only 3000 yards away, so the rear waggon lines are up fairly near.
Entry.316: Yanks hopped over this morning & are going well up to date. It is rather dull weather & cold. Horses are grazing all day so there is little work to do.
Entry.317:
Very dull & is cold. Horses were grazing all day again,so we also had a cool off. The village of Busigny is close at and. Collected vegetables for the cook. We are living well in that line. The village is not damaged by shells. Speaking to a French civilian he was telling us his experience under German rule for four years. Every civilian had to salute the Hun officers, by springing to attention & taking hat off. The Fritzs' lived on oats & potatoes & black bread, the latter

is exceedingly bitter). The horses too form a diet for men, that is the worst portions of the animal. He also said that the men would not fight unless they were made & officers are always with revolver ready making them work. They treat prisoners of war very roughly too. He was glad to be free again.
Entry.318: Still very cold & wet. The weather is breaking up fastly. Did little all day, having a complete rest.
Entry.319: On stable piquet today so had & cool off again. We are living very well on the French vegetable gardens, thanks to Fritz leaving them.
Entry.320:
Did little in morning, the four guns came back from Ordnance

& went into action tonight. I went up on E sub. They are billeted in a house near the guns, have quite a Home & good sleeping quarters. Fritz spoilt the look of the house yesterday by putting a 5.9 on the roof. It is raining & cold. Received a few Aussie home letters much pleasure being mine in getting them.
Entry.321: At 4pm the battery moved forward to an advanced position about 1600 yards being S.O.S. Put the guns into action & then turned in for the night in a loft of a house. He shelled us all night from 4.2" to 8 inch stuff, being on the corner of cross road in village we were in the centre of it. Each minute we thought he would put one through the roof, our position was one of uncertainty.
Entry.322: The Barrage opened out at 5.40 am. Fritz immediately put up on us, getting three crews in our Battery, all getting Bonzer "Blighties". As our gun was not working too good we took over A sub, but this too was not much good so we finished up on "C" Sub. He evidently expected us by the Barrage he put up. Moved forward at 11 am several hundred prisoners came in. They are of fine type. One Battalion belong to marines having anchor etc. on collars. Came up near St. Souplet, but Fritz had pushed the Yanks back to the railway line again. So we had to go back at the "Toot". Went into action behind a small village. Had a good rest, in the morning we put up another Barrage. The weather is keeping very fine. Received several Australian's letters at night.
Entry.323: Moved forward at 2 pm to a forward positon through St. Souplet which is a fair sized village, much knocked about by our Barrages. The Hun had put up a fight here, having a steep Railway Bank & river on which to defend. Many dead are abut both Yank & Fritzs' came over country some two kilos past the above mentioned village to the new position 1000 yards from front line. He put a few 5.9 near us when coming up & five Fritz planes flying low poured machine gun bullets around us. They were driven away by "anties" & a few of our 'planes. Put the guns into action & then dug ourselves in for the night. Had to shoot a few rounds at 2 am but had a good sleep otherwise.
Entry.324:
Octover 1918.

Weather is dull & cold with land mist on

It is rumoured that Fritz is evacuating here. Found two Fritz wounded in bush near by so they took them down to a dressing station. They were lucky to be alive so long. He put a few 5.9s onto the position we having to go to a flank. It makes you "windy" these few shots now & then. The weather is unsettled. Wrote a few letters.
Entry.325: Today has been uneventful, rather wet & miserable. Just loafed around in tent. Had a few rounds gun fire in afternoon.
Entry.326:
Moved up to forward position at about 10 am the day being misty. Dug the gun in & stacked up the ammunition not finishing till dusk. Had to dig a humpy there being no shelter. We were too tired to sleep.

He kept us awake with shells pretty adjacent. In morning he put over a heavy Barrage but luckily it did not reach up to us. He stopped on the other side of road about two hundred yards up.
Entry.327: He put a good number of shells over onto our position, making us go to a flank on a couple of occasions. It makes the position uncomfortable when you know he is on it. Turned in & at 1.30 am we had to shoot a barrage, the Tommies hopping the "Bags" although on our sector the objectives were not too great. On our left it extended to some extent. All objectives were taken. He did not put any shells over at us since the stunt. Wrote several letters. The weather has cleared up again.
Entry.328: The lads have been souveniring up the line. There is not much to obtain. It is a fine day. Fixed our pit up a little.
Entry.329: It has been very quiet today & nothing of importance has happened. Wrote letters to get the Xmas mail.
Entry.330: Gave the gun a good clean up & fixed up the ammunition. Weather is dull. Received a few letters.
Entry.331: The guns pulled out of action tonight. We were not sorry. It is rumoured that we are going out for a long period of rest. We doubt it. Came through St. Souplet to waggon lines.
Entry.333:
Went to Church on Sunday morning. The Padre was not bad. It was held in an old barn ventillated with several shell holes. The following days we have been clearing the waggons, preparatory to pulling out? cleaning horselines etc & of course having a cool off. Received a few letters from home all being welcomed. At night Fritz comes over with his bombs. It is a nuisance as all fires have to be "doused" & lights out. It makes the night so long having no alternative but to turn in. A plane came a 'fritzer" last night. It was a fine sight, as all his flares came out in different colours. He managed the plane

well. It is very cold these days.
Entry.334: Did the usual camp routine today & had a cool off. It is rumoured that we have to go into action again. Evidently some general looking out for a D.S.O. The lads are very unsettled about it & with a little more of this unfairness could cause trouble. Being attached to the Tommies our rations are very light; one has to buckle up a hole or two.
Entry.335:
The guncrews went up this morning to the position to dig gun pits & to get everything ready for stunt. We went up on a G.S. waggon. Fritz made the road somewhat unpleasant with his 5.9 "gifts". Eventually arrived up there after a

two hours travel having to go through Le Cateau& a few villages recently taken. The former place is a rather large town & railhead much knocked about in recent operations. Fritz made a good job of the main line by blowing some hundred yards up across a gully. On some of the trucks could be seen "froggy" furniture some Hun officer was about to send away to his home. A shell of ours decided the destination of same. Dug gun pits till dusk when guns & ammunition came up. I returned with the waggons to waggon lines to cool off for a while, having been up the longest last time. Fritz planes bombed at night but nothing came our way. It is very cold at night (in front of the village of Pommereuil our last stunt)
Entry.336: The waggon lines moved forward from Estcaufaux to the left front of Le Cateau, along a steep railway bank. Put up horse lines etc & dug a home in the bank, which proved hard digging having to pick practically all of it. We appreciated a hot tea & an immediate turn in to bed despite the bumps on the floor. Ammunition went up at night. The officers seem to arrange things so that men will be inconvenienced as much as possible. We have with us a very incompetent officer who we believe is responsible for such bad management.
Entry.337:
The stunt came off this morning

& was a success except in one place. Ammunition went up in afternoon. It is bitterly cold with rain. Our humpy is ventillated rather too much for this weather consequently we suffer from cold feet early in the morniings.
Entry.338:
Gun limbers & waggons went up, as we are pulling out. The limbers came back the gun remaining in action. More bad management in Battery & horses & men on half rations. It is raining fairly heavy. Guns pulled out at 2 pm, the whole battery moving to better waggon lines in a large factory nearby. The horses are sheltered & we are in the factory having

a dry billet at last. Several fires were made in the hall (?) and soon we had our clothes drying & water on for a bath. Found ample coal in the engine room. The hot bath & change of clothes went well. Had a sing song when we turned in.
Entry.339:
Did a good deal of washing today having a big fire to dry them. The horses are in another part of the factory having a good floor & sheltered from wind & rain. Went down to Brigade H.Q. with a despatch. Le Cateau is a fine town, having some fine buildings in it. It has a theatre, at present a Tommy Concert Party is showing & a cinema. Fritz had had the interior altered a little putting his

colours around the walls. The weather is very unsettled. Received a lot of Aussie mail today. Did a rough guard of twenty four hours over a chap who got 21 days for drinking rum sent to pits. Wrote many letters until I got sick of writing the same news.
Entry.340:
Did little today kept the fire warm. The drivers are on their harness getting it polished up. A usual stunt when we are out of action. They (the heads)? think more of such things than of giving a man a clean change of clothes & a bath. It is still raining. Went to the Cinema show down town with several of the Boys of the Sub. Had a good time getting into the show, the crowd being great

& we made a push. Beat any of the Sydney crowds for force anyway. The show was good. We sang all the way home for all seem happy now that the war is seemingly near the end. Made cocoa & toast on our arrival home then had another sing song. It is a change to be able to go to bed knowing that the roof is waterproof, also one can stand up to dress or undress without bumping wet canvass.
Entry.341: Cleaned the waggons this morning & oiled them over. Wrote letters at night. Had a sing song after the chaps came from the concert. I did not go having a sore foot & could not walk quickly.
Entry.342: Did the usual work in the morning. In afternoon Sam Honey & self went down to see the "Encores" showing at the theatre down town. The show was excellent, all actors being professionals. The orchestra was all that could be wished for. At night we received Comforts from Citizens War Chest Fund of Sydney. They included shirts, socks, tobacco, sugar, cocoa & boiled lollies & games. Had a game of draughts & dominoes finishing up with a game of 500. The circles around the fires have debates about the end of war & the conditions. It passes the time away & much speculation goes on whether Fritz will accept our terms or not.
Entry.343: It is very cold this morning, a heavy frost being on the ground. All our blankets went away to be fumigated this morning. Did usual work in stables in afternoon had a few games of cards. Had a letter from Ern Gullen in Blighty, he is coming over again in a few days,. The "Plonk" men (D.A.C.) went back today, the old Battery men returning to the Battery after their two month spell. Wrote letters at night.
Entry.344:
Horses were let loose to graze so I was minding them, whilst doing this job I received the good news that the actual fighting had cease, Fritz having accepted terms of Armistice. Everyone needless

to say was overjoyed on hearing such news. The Major gave the boys a barrel of wine to celebrate this historical occasion. Some were merry but it was a good date to be merry on. It is hard to realise that such news is true. Many flares were put up in and around Le Cateau.
Entry.345:
It is not so cold this morning. Went to a Church Parade but the Padre had been evacuated the previous night so the Parade returned home & had till watering time off. Am makinga couple of serviette rings to take home as a souvenier of the Great La Guerre. Had an easy time today. Wrote letters at night. It is fairly cold & the circles around

the fires are fairly large. The larger the crowd the greater the yarns & stronger the laugh?
Entry.346: Preparing for the G.O.C.s inspection which is to take place on Monday. Oiled the vehicles & cleaned the guns. It is very cold. Bob Forsyth came up about 10 am on bicycle his unitbeing billeted in La Cateau. Had a yarn to him. Looks exceedingly well after his Blighty Leave & rest down on the coast with the remainder of Corps. At night I went down to his billet which is a rather luxurious abode for a private. The place is furnishd out with Froggy material & is quite homely. Had a walk around the town. Many civilians are coming back to this town.
Entry.347: Cleaning up the waggon park etc. Did not work too hard. Arthur Pinkerton came back from base tonight. Was pleased to see him back. Had a strole down town to Corps Canteens. It is very chilly at nights now & bed is favourite place.
Entry.348: Had a half holiday today so played a little game of football, enjoying same. It is good exercise. Sat around the fire at night yarning. Received a few Aussie letters.
Entry.349: Did little work today. Cleaned up the waggons again. It is cold & dull. The ground is frozen over & very slppery being like glass.
Entry.350: Worked hard today cleaning up generally for tomorow. Being tired at night went to bed early. The waggon park is a picture, every vehicle being oiled up & all brasswork polished. The harness too is well cleaned & polished.
Entry.351: Had to clean the frost off the waggons & cold job too it proved. Major General McLagan C.O. of 4th Div. came around and inspected us at 11am being pleased with the outfit. So he should be. Went down to the canteen at night. Today saw the first snowfall. It was cold; that is the weather. Wrote letters at night. Received a parcel from Mrs. King of Dubbo, socks, etc.
Entry.352: Packed the waggons etc. during the day. At night four of us went down o the theatre. It was an excellent show, the best I have seen in the military. All actors were professionals. The staging was all that could be desired & the orchestra first class, therebeing about thirty instruments.
Entry.353:
Pulled out at 9am proceeding on our way to Germany. Passed through Basuel &Cathlon arriving at La Groise about noon. It is about 8 kilos from Le Cateau. Pulled into a paddock alongside an old brewery. We are billeted in the latter. Have good billets. It is very cold at night. Very frosty.

Thursday 21st November

Did a little cleaning up. The horses were freezing most of the day. The days are beautiful whilst the sun is up. Had a read at night.
Entry.354: Packed up ourgear & took it down to the waggons packing up the vehicles, thinking we were moving off. It was only an inspection. The men counted the Colonel out. All were annoyed. It is no joke packing up for nothing. Watched the first Division passby. The 1st & 2nds Brigades went by.
Entry.355:
Normber 1918

Did usual work. Watched the Infantry go by. The 4th Division went by. Did not see Capt Brooks with the 46th Battalion. On Guard at night. It was cold too. The nights are clear with a good moon,
Entry.356: Received a letter from Os Ferns who is still in hospital. On guard till 5pm wrote a letter home today. The 4th &
Entry.357: Brigades went by today. It is very cold.
Entry.358: Had a game of Rugby Union this afternoon. All enjoyed the game, it will get a man into condition a few games this weather. Had a walk at night, being fairly stiff from running.
Entry.359: Packed up ready to move out in the morning. It is raining and very cold.
Entry.360:
Had an early "Reveille" moving out at 9am. Passed through the small village of Favril then through

Prisches somewhat larger than Pavril. Cartignes is rather more of a town than a village; it is full of Australians. We were supposed to billet here but there being no room, we came onto the next village by name Boulogne a small quiet place with its fine church & hovels all around. None of these villages have suffered much by shell fire, for it was about there that Fritz started a running fight & artillery was not used much. All roads were blown up by him & bridges. He did this work well.
Entry.361:
Up early as we moved out at 8.30am pasing through Cantraine, Semeries (Les Grandes Foress) and Semeries coming to thelarge village of Sains from here we went through Ramousies

to the village of Liessies where we are billeting for some little time. The country passed through today is very rich, & one cant help noticing the small fields in comparison to down in south of France. The country looks very picturesque with small villages studed here & there amongst the green fields. The houses are well built in this area. Put up the horse lines. We are billeted in a house & are not so bad off in this respect. The weather is unettled & cold.
Entry.362: Made new horse-lines & cleaned the waggons. It was cold work too. Received a little mail at night. This village is very dead. There are good many civilians in the town, they seem a poor lot.
Entry.363: Cleaned up the waggons and repacked them. In the afternoon we had a practice at football. Have debating society of an impromptu kind on the ground floor of our billet, all seated around the fire. It passes the time away & good arguments arise.
Entry.364: Had a church parade at 10 am. it was not bad, but there was no music. In afternoon we had a scratch match (Rugby Union) with the 37th Brg. They won by 6 to nil.
Entry.365:
Had exercise in afternoon for football. Given a pair of horses & harness to look after, so any

promoted to acting Driver. How pleased I am? Heedless to say I did little to harness. At night we had a good argument on Royalty versus President with reference to British Empire. It was heated too.
Entry.366: Had the usual work to do, They have started the Education Scheme and it seems to be favourite with the lads these long idle nights. The weather is unsettled. Was on guard? tonight on Gun Park.
Entry.367:
Played the 38th Battery today. It was a fast game. We won by 6 to nil. Had exercise at night. The civilians in this village are dying off

having no food. Rations not having been provided for the people released from Germany & returning. The Brigade volunteered to give the people half their rations. They appreciated it, no only the giving of it but also the reality of having a little white bread. The people now show themselves, as they were not wont to do when we arrived, evidently being frightened. We are now sworn friends They certainly are very thin & poor.
Entry.368:
We let the horses go early in the morning into the field. They have a good time grazing & are putting on condition to some order. The Australian Rules players played the 38th but lost.

Had exercise at night, went for five kilo walk & sprint, then went to the Education school. There are many subjects from which you can chose. The idea is to prepare all for civil occupation on demobilisation in Australia in near future. Some of lecturers are very good. Receiving many letters from Aussie up to Sept 30th.
Entry.369:
Played the 37th Btl today. It was a hard game & the large crowd were highly excited rom the onset, there being so much money on the match. The final score was 3 all. It was a hard game. Wrote a letter at night but am too tired to do much. It was a glorious day with the sun up. It is rumoured that the Jan-Feb 15

men met with a railway accident some being killed, several severely injured. Some from this battery are amongst the later. It is stiff luck having got through the war and then get an issue whilst on the way home.
Entry.370: The weather is very fine. The Australian Rules game was played today, the 37th Battery won after a hard game by very few. On guard at night. Did till 10.30 pm then went to bed.
Entry.371: Rugby Footballers played a scratch match against the 37th Battery they wom 21 to nil. A very funny match it was too, there being chaps playing who did not know the rules. Had a debate at night
Entry.372: Had an impromptu Debate at night. Wrote a few letters. The weather is rather dull, received camera from Blighty, thus my greatest friend is again with me.
Entry.373: Played the 110th Battery on their grounds, the day was wretched, raining with a strong wind blowing. They won by 5 to nil. Their forwards were to heavy for us. Half of our team was knocked out. I for one was "out" for five minutes owing to colliding with one of their side; my head proved the hardest for his was split open. All that I have is a headache & will have fr sometime to come.
Entry.374: Had a football meeting, was to play a scratch match but the weather was too wet. Put the night in by having a Rough House. It was a rough house too. Put the football through the roof. Certainly doesn't say much for roof.
Entry.375: Had a debate between 37th Bty & 39th, the former taking affirmative side of the question "Should White Australia Policy be modified". It was a good debate the 37th winning by 7%. Packed up as we leave tomorrow.
Entry.376:
We were leading Battery of 10th Brigade so left early. Pulled out at 9 am passing through

good country which appears to be very rich. The farm houses are all in the fields, a thing one does not often see in France, most farmers congregating in the village. Fritz had evidently left the people alone, as all villages were intact & civilians carrying on as usual. We passed through the village of Eppe-Sauvage, then Rance, which is a fairly large village up to date & has some fine buildings in it. Of course the Church stands out for largeness & beauty. We arrived at Froid-Chappelle where we stayed the night. Had a good billet. At night we had a chat to a civilian family where we were billeted. One soon picks up the "lingo" when you talk to them much.
Entry.377: Pulled out about 10am passing through the fairly large village of cerfontaine. The next villages in order of passing were Senzeille, Villers Deux Eglises and Villers Le Gambon where we were billeted for the night. Had a stroll around the village which is of ordinary size. The civilians soon grabbed a horse that was injured in one of the waggons, & had it skinned & dressed the same night. The cafe were crowded a fact quite obvious to all who understand the A.I.F. A passenger train goes through this village. We are billeted in a large factory and our beds are hard being made of concrete.
Entry.378: We did not leave till 11am today as the 11th Brigade led the way. Only passed through one village by name Rosee. Across the streets they had archways of trees & flags to celebrate the victorius entry of troops. Arrived at the small village of Flavion where we have to spend our Xmas. It is a dull uneventful place. The Brigade is camped here. Billets are scattered all over the place. We are camping in the school.
Entry.379:
Did usual work getting things cleaned upn. The horse lines are some distance from the parade. The old hores will have a rough spin during cold & wet season,no rugs having

arrived. Went to bed early there being nothing else to do.
Entry.380:
The other three Batteries of Brigade have moved to surrounding villages so we have this village to ourselves. Looked around and obtained a bonzer room for two of us. Have a bar bed. Just like home. Hot water, plenty of coffee etc. The people are nice & we have great fun trying to compree each other. It is hard work, but we are improving each day. Practice makes perfect 
so they say
. Pinkerton is staying at the place with me. Most of te chaps found private joints to live in.
Entry.381:
It is a wretched day raining and a blowing icy cold wind.



little happened worth relating today. Received some Aussie mail up to the
Entry.383: Left this house that were were staying at to a better one; although I did not like leaving the people being so nice. The Madame cried when we left, she thouigh us Bon fellows. The other place is nearer the Cook House, a big consideration these bleak days.
Entry.385:
Had a scratch match between "A" & "B" teams Rugby football, the former winning by umpteen points. All the lads have settled down in private homes, so we are dug in for the

winter. The people are very nice and homely. The weather has been wretched, that boing a good name for it. Rain and wind that takes the breath away. Hard a snow fall on the night of the
Entry.386: The people have lived more at church than in their homes this week. They are great church goers. Have not received any mail of late.
Entry.387:
In the morning we received a parcel each from the Comforts Fund Sydney, just a reminder that the folk out yonder still thought of us. They were greatly appreciated by the boys. At 10am about ten of us walked five kilos

to see some Hun "Bombers". they are immense 'planes, have two machine guns, carry sixteen 25lb bombs, and several aerial torpedoes. Have two enormous engines, and carry about six persons. Took a few snaps of them. Xmas dinner came off at 5 pm. It was a success. Some of the chaps made fools f themselves, too much booze. The officers and Sergeants waited on the tables. After a few speeches appropriate to the events were delivered, the dinner party broke up. Several of E Subites had a sing songtill 9pm. The day passed off successfully.
Entry.388:
Did little today. It is very cold and windy. Had

practice at football at night.
Entry.389: It is a cold wet wretched day. The wind is the limit. Played the 37th Battery Rugby this afternoon, in rain & gale. I defy anyone to name a match that has been played in weather to beat it. Our hands were numbed, legs dead & body wringing wet. We won by 11 to nil. Am now feeling very sick but in morning will be OK.
Entry.390: Did usual work during the day which does not amount to much these times. The weather is wretched.
Entry.391:
Had a little exercise for football

as we play the final match of Brigade competition tomorrow. All the folk of this village turn out in their best on Sunday. You would hardly recognise them for the same people of the remaining six days.
Entry.392: Played the 110th Battery Rugby Football today and won by 6 to 3. We had the best of the game although they played very hard and lost their block in second half. We thus won the Brigade Competition. All of our side are sore. The 110 play dirty. The wather was ideal for the game. The match caused great interest.
Entry.393:
Did very little today being rather stiff and sore. My shins are

well scarred alsoback and neck. All the players are in the same way.
Entry.394:
Had a strole around the village. This is the Belgians Day out, when they all collect in family groups & have their feast. Consisting thisyear of Home made cake, very much like our pan cakes although they are baked. They fill up a gap nevertheless. At night the Battery had a dinner run by the men who invited the officer & NCOs. The spread was all that could be desired, and following the dinner we had an impromptu concert by the Brigade Concert Party. It was a most enjoyable evening, much more so that that of Xmas when Mr



"Booze" spoilt it to an extent. The weather is freezing cold but dry.
Entry.395: Leave to Charleroi is now obtainable so will join and see the place. Have not received any mail for some time. "Pink" & self went down to see some F Sub mates, so we had a game of six hand Euchre, putting in an enjoyable evening, finishing up with a good suppeer.
Entry.396: Received two small parcels tonight from Aussie. Had a yarnaround the fire at the QM store. The weather is still wet and dreary. A few of the chaps went to Charleroi today, and some to Dinant.
Entry.397: Did little work today & there is no news to write about. One can only yarnor write these days as there is no night sport and there is a great dearth in reading material, this way. The life is very monotonous. Took a few snaps.
Entry.398: The village is dressed up today one would not know the civilians when they are "togged" up. they are great church goers. At night Pink and myselfwent down to the the people that we left some time ago having a "yarn" as much as we could compree of it.
Entry.399: The "heads" were around inspecting today. In the afternoon the
Entry.401: Brigade Rugby football. I played in the forwards for the former, our Battery being well represented in the Brigade team. We won 8 to 6 a very hard fast clean game. Had to ride to the ground which is at 38th Battery Ostemereefour kilos. Am dead tired tonight and sore. It has been a fine day quite an unusual occurrence. Wrote a few letters.
Entry.402: Wth a mate (Corporal Tunks) I went to Dinant to have a look at this Historical town or what is left of it after the Fire Sticks of the Huns in
Entry.403:
had wrought what damagethey could. Werode on horseback, against a stiff wind

which is not the best of company. The road in is very good, and the fifteen kilos were covered in a little over an hour. The town lies in a deep gorge or gully through which the river Meuse flows or at this time is fast approaching rapids. The river is very swollen and houses on bank are under water. the scenery is superb. Looking across the river you see the old fort some five hundred feet up, built on the soldrock jutting out, and predominating the whole country around it. This fort was originallt built in 1040 by Prince Ereque of Liege, was destroyed in 1466 by Charles 1, rebuilt in 1530 by Edward de la Mareq Liege and was captured in 1554 by Henry 11.

from the river, steps numbering 408 were built up to the fort which was restored in 1675 by Louis XIV. In 1902 the Society of Brussels bought it for 42,000 francs. The Germans arrived in Dinant on the
Entry.404: 1914, the French three days later. There was a fight at this fort on the
Entry.406:
The Hun troops shot down in cold blood on the 23rd & 24th August 1914, 650 inhabitants, among whom were 80 women &several youngsters. 1200 houses were destroyed by fire. 450 inhabitants were deported in 1914 to Cassels (Germany) and 150 in 1916. The British arrived in Dinant on the 23rd November 1918.

On the 25th April 1916, the Kaiser visited the fort of Dinant accompanied by twenty officers. As soon as we arrived there & found stables for the two horses we had a good meal, for fifteen kilo rides makes one hungry. When we asked for encore the waiter opened his eyes. Climbed to the top of the fort taking some good views as we went up. One can get some fine panoramic views from the top. All the ruins have been cleaned away so the destruction is not quite so noticeable. It is a place worth seeing. Marks on some of the walls can be seen where the people were lined up and shot. Arrived home at dusk, a little tired & stiff.

Wednesday 8th January 1919.

It is a most perfect Day, the best that we have had at this village. Our Sports too had been arranged for this day so success was guaranteed before the events started.

Had the usual events, horse events attractingthemostspectators.Civilianscame out in large numbers to see the show. The 16th Battalion Band was a great asset to the afternoon's enjoyments. It is a very good band. Everyone enjoyed the turn out. Received a large Aussie mail at night up to 23rd November. By it the people in Australia went mad at the news of Armistice. Was sorry to hear of Joe Coopers death.

having seen him under a month before his death. It
was
hard luck.

Thursday 9th January 1919.

Did little today. It is cold and wet. Developed films at night.

Friday 10th Monday to
Entry.407: This village is very slow, the evenings are generally put in over the fire or writing letters. The moon now full helps to cheer the place a little. Developed films on one night of the 39th Football teams. On the morning of the 13th twenty six of the boys left for England to embark for Aussie. It cuts the unit about when chaps leave like this. Everyone knows each other and all are friends. On the
Entry.408:
Pink & myself

went into Charleroy a distance of about twenty kilos by train from Florennes. Had to walk to Florennes from Flavianover seven Kilos.

Charleroy is a large town, having many suburbs, population of several thousands, it is much larger than Amiens. Boasts of Theatres Cinemas etc. The streets are narrow, have a good service of Electric Trams. The main buildings are the Bank & Railway Station.

It would be a very dear place to live in, food is a High Price.

At night we went to a cinema then had supper and turned in a good Hotel. Charged 10 Francs for the room. Food onmenu being Steak & Chips 6 Francs. One could generally do an encore.

During the day we stroled around 



the town, looked at the Museum & another Cinema. The Meuse River runs through the centre of town. This place has not been damaged or destroyed by Fritz. Left a six and arrived Home near 10pm having to walk the Florennes Flavian track again. On the
Entry.409:
we had another Dance but the crowd was too great for the Hall as Grand Pa Ma Aunts etc turned up also. The Curis against dancing in the Hall, but the people ignore Him. He saw a General today about stopping the soldiers from using it. I don't that he will succeed somehow. The people here go to church to midday then after that hour, they can have a "bust up". Dance orany kind of amusement.

On the
Entry.410: several of the lads went to Namur to have a look round. It is not a bad place about the same size as Charleroy. I played Football with the Brigade against the DAC winning by 9-3. It has been a fine day the best that we have had up to date although it is freezing. Received a few parcels from Home during last week.
Entry.412:
Since last writing little has happened in the way of news. Have had heavy falls of snow which has caused much amusement and a certain amount of inconvenience when walking. One has to be so careful otherwise you will soon

be on the Broad of your Back and youinvariable fall heavy. The youngsters of the village are enjoying the Winter sports of tobogganningon the Hills around and in the village itself. Have had no mail during this period. Had a couple of dances during the time that has elapsed. Tom Burgess one of my pals went Home on
Entry.413:
instant. He is a student at Sydney Uni - studying for a Doctor. A few civilian friends gave him a very nice dinner on 26 several of 
the boys
 beingthere. Went into Florennes to see him off & to bring back the Horses. It was a slippery trip the road being frozen over & we had no freshcaps

in the horses shoes. There is no mail coming in owing to the strike on the Railways.
Entry.414: Did little today had a heavy snow fall during the night and day, so kept near the fire and had a read. The gunscame back today from the Ordnance Works.
Entry.415: The people are all going to church. They like the church or have to go. The Curhas a good hand over them. He has given the idea of stopping the dances up. There us a Fancy Dress Ball on tonight.
Entry.416: Nothing of importance happened to day. At night Kept a fire warm and had a good read.
Entry.417: It is very cold today, one of the coldest this year. Took a few snaps of snow pictures. Read a Book at night.
Entry.418:
ebruary 1919

Heavy fall of snow which is still falling, over a foot deep. Received pass for Paris in lieu of Blighty leave so have been busily preparing to leave tomorrow. Can hardly credit it that I am actually going at last. A dance was held in Flavion tonight but I did not go down.
Entry.419:
Left the Battery at 2pm going in with the cook's cart to Corenne. Had then to go on to Florennes a distance of five kilos on foot. No joke in early two feet of snow. Arrived at Charleroi about

6PM having tea, then went to a Picture Show or rather a Vaudeville. Something like the Casino in Alexandria. It was a good show. Left at 9PM as the train was supposed to leave at 9.30PM but did not pull out till midnight. About forty chaps in our truck and the train did four miles an hour, stopping twice between each telegraph post. Chummed up with a second Div Infantry chap also going to Paris on Leave. We intended getting out at Mons but the train went through too quick. had no alternative but to go on to Lille as distance of forty miles.
Entry.420:
All day we watched the miles go slowly by and indeed







a6635331.html

they did pass slowly. Often had stops of an hour to let passenger trains go by. At 7pm we came near Lille so Hopped off and walked the rest into the town. Fixed up at a Hotel we had a walk around the town which is rather large having a fine square, streets and buildings. One portion of it has been destroyed by the Boche. Had a good sleep after the train journey, about the worst that I have ever experienced. I'm going home in a much better train.
Entry.421:
Took a few snaps in morning. It is freezing cold 11 degrees Fahrenheit. Left by the passenger train for Paris at 11am.

passing through the shell torned country of Lens, Bethune, Albert and Amiens. It now appears as a desolate waste & one can see at a glance the immensity of war. Arrived at Paris five hours late but we arrived that is the main thing. Went to a Restaurant and had a feed then turned in at an Hotel.
Entry.422:
Had a look around near the station then found our way via the tube to the Barracks to get our pass stamped back. The tubes are similar to those in London, althoough the directions & different lines are much easier to find in Paris, there being a few main lines. Most of the room



in the compartments are for standing there being few seats in the car. Crowds of people block the Boulevards & streets which are certainly fine being very wide with wide footpaths. The buildings are all of a uniform height about four storey. This sets off the street to the eye. Avenues of trees (now leafless) adorned the streets Boulevards & places. We walked for a couple of hours along the Rue Madelaine, Italiens & Poissonaire. This is all one Boulevarde but in Paris the names of street is only for a number of "blocks". This confuses one new to the city. We passed some very fine buildings, as the Madeleine Church, the Society church of Paris where all "the" marriages take place

next we came to Opera the second finest of theatres in the world. It took several millions to build the Architecture is superb, We finally arrived at the Republique a fine Place. Had tea at the Army & Navy League Club, then found out the way to Alhambra. It was not much of a programme, too much fuffling, became monotonous. Amstopping at the Florida Hotel near the Madeleine Church.
Entry.423:
With a party from the Y.M.C.A and guide we went to see the Palace of Versailles which is about twenty kilos from the city getting there by train. The palace and its wonderful park constitutes the grandest ex-Royal residence in the world, and its Historic association

covers over 225 years. We arrived there about 12 noon having dinner before going up to the Palace. Versailles is a large place and very busy at present owing to the Peace Conference now taking place. The motor cars outside the Palace numbers several hundred. Around the Palace wheel to wheel are thousands of captured enemy guns of all calibre. The Architecture is the very best that I have seen. It leaves London far in the distance. It was built by Louis XIII, enlarged by Louis XIV and inhabited by the French Kings up to the Revolution. It is now a museum. The different styles of Architecture of the XVIIth & XVIIIth cneturies are very pronounced on the latter extensions of Louis XIV. There is a magnificant Parade Ground and stables at

the back of the Palace. The Court yards are also great, having statues around it with an equestian statue of Louis XIV in bronze in the centre. Entering the Palace we were astounded with the luxury of everything, everything so grand and magnificent. There are huge dancing Rooms, magnificent paintings all rooms being highly decorativce the ceilings in particular. The main room is the Glass Gallery built in the time of Louis XIV. On the ceiling is painted in thirty scenes, the History of Louis XIV between 1662 & 1678. The Gallery is 244 feet long, 34 feet broad and 42 feet high. Each of the 17 windows overlooking the gardens has a corresonding arch decorated with mirrors with 24 groups of

children in the cornice, models by the best scuptors of the time of Louis XIV. The most important Court fetes took place in this Glass Gallery. Some of these were - The fete in honouring the Queen of England 1855, Coronation of King of Prussia as Emperor of Germany 1871, & the solemn celebration of the centenary of the States-General by President Carnot & all the ministers of state 5 May 1889. You can get a wonderful view of the gardens from the windows, which extends for over two miles all of it being well planned out. Louis XIV bedroom is magnificent. He was known as the sun King, he had all his Rooms facing the sun. At either end of the Glass Gallery there is a room, one Hall

of Peace, the other Hall of War. The Glass Gallery will most likely be the scene of the Peace Conference of this age. The Queen's staircase is most beautiful having pure marble steps and leads to the main wing of the building. The Gallery of Battles which is 150 feet longer than the Glass Gallery was built in 1836 by Louis Philippe. It contains a set commencing at the left of majestic compositions on the principal battles in French History, all are wonderful paintings. The Gallery is decorated with 16 bronze tablets on which are inscribed names of Princes, Admirals & Generals who died fighting; also 80 busts reproducing the features of some of these Heroes. Leaving the Palace we went down to the gardens which are immense and grand. You get a beautiful look at the Palace

from these gardens, with its projecting centre piece and its two great wings. the length of the facade is 1350 feet. The Fountain Garden is wonderful. The ornamentation of this garden presents the finest collection of bronzes in the worldwhich were modelled by the greatest sculptors of the time of Louis XIV. Next to this garden is the Garden ofLatona. The Basin of Latona is wonderful. The marble group represents the Goddess with her two children, Apollo & Diana. She is imploring Jupiter to punish the Lycians, who insulted her when she asked them for a drink. Next we went to the lawn or Royal walk. It is 1079 feet long & 208 feet broad, although when we saw it, it was covered with frozen snow and the canal frozen over, with thousands

of people skating on it. The basin of Apollo is wonderful. The group represents the carof Apollo, the sun-God, who as Greek mythology relates, rose from the ocean every morning to illuminate the earth & at evening plunged in its waves. It is now popularly styled "the car stuck in the mud". The Fountain of Neptuneis another wonderful sight. Leaving the Gardens behind we went to see the Trianons, Great & small. The former was built for Madame Maintenon, the latter for Marie-Antoinette. the Kings etc came and lived in the Houses to escape the formality of the Palace at times. The Trianons are much simpler, although built with fine marble, the interior being not so Highly decorative. Visited the Museam of carriages & Harness

of the crown stables. The coronation car, built in 1825 for Charles X is wonderful weighing 15,432 ilbs. Returned to the city having tea & at night went to see The Folies Bergererather a good show. There is a Huge Promenade at back of the theatre Hall, where most people go at intervals. Music & all life is there.
Entry.424:
Taking a trip with the tour round Paris we first visited the original burying place of Louis XVIth & Marie Antoinette at La Chapelle Expiatoire in the city. After their execution at Place de la Concorde, their bodies were "dumped" in this place withtheir guard. They were removed years after. The place de LaConcorde is perhaps the most beautiful square in Europe and certainly one of the most Historical

In 1770 a terrible event occurred in the place. During a firework display given to celebrate the marriage of the Dauphon (Louis XVI) with Marie-Antoinette a panic & stampede took place some 1200 people were killed. The Guilllotine was erected on the square and both the King & Marie Antoinette lost their heads in this place some years later with thousands of their followers. In 1814 Prussian Troops encamped here, English the following year and Germans again in 1871 after the capitulation of Paris. History has also been made in these days during the war. The mourning of Strasburg & Lille. From here we went to Montmatre the northern part of the great city. This part once represented the brains, the wit and the genius of France. It was

the Home of the artists and of Bohemia. Most noted in this district are the night cafes, which were the life of Paris at one time. The former one was started in 1882, & many gifted and witty artists & poets have since become celebrated as Maurice Donnaif the Academician of today. Leaving these interesting quarters we visited the Church of the Sacre Coeur (Sacred Heart) which is built on a large hill - considered sacred ground. the building of the Romanesque Church of the Sacred Heart with its Byzantine Dome was decided on by the National Assembly in 1874, and the expense has been enormous. The foundations

which go to bottom of Hill cost 4 million francs. The distant view of the church is more interesting than the near one for the church is sombre and has nothing particularlyattractive about it. A famous dancing Hall by name of Moulin Rouge a very old place, very popular with the Parisians. Dancing took place of some kind followed by copious suppers. This place opened at 11pm & carried on till break of day. It was burnt down quite recently.
